attributes.title: (Re)Building Trust. Investigating the effects of open science badges  on perceived trustworthiness in journal articles.
attributes.description:
The Replication Crisis diminishes trust in empirical sciences and with it the perceived value of science (Lupia, 2018). Open Science Practices (i.a. open data, open analysis script, open materials) are an increasingly popular approach to deal with challenges in replication and to rebuilt trust (Geukes, Schönbrodt, Utesch, Geukes, & Back, 2016). First investigations could, however, deliver no evidence toward the effects of Open Science Practices (OSP) on trustworthiness (Wingen, Berkessel, & Englich, 2019). The study investigated the effect on a discipline level (psychology) with an abstract description of OSP. Within the ongoing discussion about incentives for OSP (e.g. badges), we want to shift the focus from discipline level to concrete individual journal articles and consider epistemic beliefs of readers to play a moderating role (Merk & Rosman, 2018): Will visible OSP (vs. not visible vs. visibly non-OSP) foster perceived trustworthiness when reading journal articles of empirical studies? Will multiplistic epistemic beliefs moderate the relationship between OSP and trustworthiness?

The design will include three conditions: visible Open Science Practices (visOSP), Practices not visible (nonvis) and visible non-Open Science Practices (nonOSP). Two of the conditions are randomized within person. Realizing all three conditions within person would highlight the variation between conditions as too obvious and thus undermine blinding of subjects.
visOSP condition: Subjects receive a title page of an empirical study (Title, Abstract, Keywords, Introduction, ...) together with three Open Science badges. The badges are explained using hints in style of speech bubbles and indicate that the authors engaged in the OSP open data, open analysis script and open materials.
nonvis condition: Subjects receive a title page of an empirical study (Title, Abstract, Keywords, Introduction, ...) with no further information on Open Science, reflecting a "standard" journal article.
nonOSP condition: Subjects receive a title page of an empirical study (Title, Abstract, Keywords, Introduction, ...) together with three Open Science badges. The badges are explained using hints in style of speech bubbles and indicate that the authors did not engage in the OSP open data, open analysis script and open materials. As participants are exposed to more than one condition, we create all three conditions for three different empirical studies (topics). This way we avoid participants to see one study topic twice under different conditions, which would undermine the blinding.
Measured variables are perceives trustworthiness: We apply the Muenster Epistemic Trustworthiness Inventory (Hendriks, Kienhues, & Bromme, 2015) with all three subscales. However, as dependent variable we will only employ the subscale integrity. The other two subscales are used for further exploratory analyses. Topic-specific multiplism: We apply the subscale of topic specific multiplism from Merk et al. (2017) Topic-specific consistency: We apply the three item-measure from Merk et al. (2017), Treatment check: We test the perceived openness/ transparency of the empirical study. Additional small set of demographic variables will be assessed.

attributes.title: Nursing and Compassionate Care in the Age of Artificial Intelligence: A Scoping Review
attributes.description: The purpose of this scoping review is to summarize what is known from the literature on how digital health technologies that utilize artificial intelligence will influence nursing practice and compassionate patient care.

summary.value: This scoping review protocol is currently being submitted for publication. Please contact corresponding authors for more information. Please note that this review was previously registered under the title "Nursing and Compassionate Care in a Technological World: A Scoping Review".

attributes.title: Transient autobiographical memory enhancement to improve the efficacy of CBT tasks

q1.value: Transient autobiographical memory enhancement to improve the efficacy of CBT tasks.

q3.value:
Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is currently the gold-standard treatment for depression. CBT techniques draw upon an individual’s autobiographical memory for their personal past, and require the individual to imagine future events, with the aim of changing the negative beliefs and assumptions that underpin dysfunctional models of the self and the world. Many of the core elements of CBT rely on cognitive processes (e.g., cognitive reappraisal, problem solving) that depend on the ability to recall specific, autobiographical information. For example, a commonly-used CBT technique involves asking an individual to evaluate the validity of a maladaptive assumption or belief (e.g., I am a total failure) by gathering specific information from their past which may act as evidence against the belief (e.g., I made a tasty dinner last week). Autobiographical memory processes are commonly disrupted in depression. People with depression show a chronic bias towards retrieving generalised summaries about the personal past, rather than memories for specific, single episodes (Dalgleish et al., 2007; Sumner, 2012; Williams et al., 2007). These biases towards overgeneralised memory retrieval, and away from recall of specific information, may thereby impair the ability to engage with, and benefit from CBT. 

Recent work has shown that inducing a more specific processing style can temporarily help people to become more specific in their memory retrieval, and enhance performance on tasks that draw upon episodic memory processes (Jing, Madore, & Schacter, 2016, 2017; Madore & Schacter, 2014; Sheldon, Gurguryan, Madore, & Schacter, 2019). Jing et al. (2016) found that an episodic specificity induction – brief training in recollecting specific details of a recent experience - enhanced problem solving and episodic reappraisal within a healthy student population. Within a depressed population, McFarland, Primosch, Maxson, & Stewart, (2017) found that the same specificity induction procedure improved performance on a subsequent problem solving task.

The current study will investigate whether a similar specificity induction procedure can help depressed individuals complete CBT exercises that rely on specific autobiographical retrieval, and whether this improves the efficacy of the CBT exercises. We will examine whether, relative to a control (general impressions about an event) induction procedure, the episodic specificity induction a) enhances the number of specific alternative interpretations generated on an episodic reappraisal task, and b) increases the number of pieces of evidence gathered in an exercise designed to evaluate the validity of a negative self-assumption (evidence gathering task). We will examine whether there is a corresponding change in strength of belief ratings (both how much it is logically believed to be true, and how much it feels true) for the challenged interpretations and assumptions. We will also explore the endurance of these effects, and possible moderating factors.

q4.value:
Primary hypotheses:
1)	On the reappraisal task, we anticipate that 
a)	Participants will generate a greater number, on average, of alternate interpretations following the specificity induction, compared with the control induction condition. 
b)	As a result of this, we anticipate a greater decrease in both logical and emotional belief ratings for the original negative appraisal for the event reappraised in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control condition.  
2)	On the evidence gathering task, we predict that
a)	A greater number of pieces of evidence will be generated following the specificity induction, relative to the control induction condition. 
b)	There will be a greater increase in strength of belief (logical, emotional) in the new, alternative assumption following the evidence gathering task completed in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition.
Secondary hypotheses:   

3)	For the evidence gathering task, we predict that there will be a greater decrease in strength of belief ratings for the original assumption in the specificity induction condition than the control condition.   

4)	Following a 1-week delay, we predict that a greater proportion of the generated a) alternative interpretations and b) pieces of evidence, will be recalled for the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition. We anticipate that this will be reflected in the strength of belief ratings, such that the change in belief ratings following each exercise endures to a greater extent for a) events reappraised and b) evidence gathered following the specificity induction compared with the control induction. 

Exploratory:

1)	We will explore whether initial feelings about the events and assumptions change to a greater extent in the specificity induction condition than the control condition. 
a)	For the reappraisal task, we will explore whether the rated intensity of feelings about the event changes to a greater extent in the specificity induction condition than in the control induction condition. 
b)	For the evidence gathering task, we will explore whether the rated intensity of feelings about the new, alternate assumption changes to a greater extent in the specificity induction condition than the control condition. 

2)	We will explore whether participants rate the a) reappraisal task and b) evidence gathering task as less difficult in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition. 

3)	We will explore whether participants rate the a) reappraisal task and b) evidence gathering task as more helpful in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition. 

4)	We will explore whether the effect of the specificity induction is moderated by factors including baseline executive function (verbal fluency, working memory, inhibitory control over memory), memory flexibility (AMT-AI score), previous completion of CBT, and depression symptom severity (BDI-II). Induction order effects (e.g., specificity first vs control first) will also be evaluated.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Individuals who score the completed CBT exercise worksheets will not be aware of the induction condition (specificity or control) under which the worksheet was completed.

question.value: Within-subjects repeated measures experiment in which all participants will complete both the a) reappraisal and b) evidence gathering tasks following each induction type (specificity induction, impressions control). The order of the induction type will be counterbalanced across induction conditions. The order of the CBT tasks will be fixed (reappraisal then evidence gathering) as, based on our clinical experience, it is likely that completing evidence gathering first would have strong effects on later completion of a reappraisal task.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants aged 18-70 who meet criteria for a current diagnosis of Major Depressive Disorder will be recruited from the MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit clinical volunteer panel. Depression status will be confirmed using the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 (First, Williams, Karg, & Spitzer, 2015). Exclusion criteria include any intellectual disability, past or present neurological disorder, and current substance or alcohol dependence. Any participants who show severe impairments on executive tests in session 1 will be excluded from the study. 

Procedure 
 
The study will be completed in two 60-90 minute sessions, completed on two separate days. During Session 1, participants will complete the memory and executive function tests; the Alternating Instructions version of the Autobiographical Memory Test (AMT-AI) , a retrieval-induced forgetting test, the Verbal Fluency Task and the Digit Span Test of working memory. Questionnaire measures of depressive symptoms (Beck’s Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II)), ruminative tendency (Ruminative Response Scale (RRS)) and dysfunctional attitudes (Dysfunctional Attitudes Scale (DAS)) will also be administered. Finally, participants will select two maladaptive assumptions and generate memories of two negative scenarios (a negative social interaction, and a time when something didn't go as planned) for use in the CBT tasks in Session 2. 

In Session 2, participants will complete an induction (specificity or control) followed by the reappraisal task, a short top-up induction, and the evidence gathering task. The procedure will then be completed with the alternate (specificity or control) induction. The order of the induction type (specificity, impressions control) will be counterbalanced. Both induction procedures involve watching a two minute video clip of individuals completing everyday activities (e.g., cooking, morning routine), and answering questions about the video. A different video will be used for each induction, and videos will be counterbalanced across task (evidence gathering, reappraisal) and induction-type. The reappraisal scenario type (negative social interaction, and a time when something didn't go as planned), and the nature of the assumption (failure, inferiority) selected for evidence gathering will be counterbalanced across induction conditions. 

One week after Session 2, participants will be contacted by telephone and/or email and asked to complete a follow-up worksheet designed to assess the endurance of the experimental effects. 


Materials and method:


Autobiographical memory test (alternating instructions):

The AMT is designed to measure ability to deliberately retrieve specific memories in response to a series of positive, negative and neutrally valenced cue words (Williams & Broadbent, 1986).  The alternating instructions AMT (AMT-AI) is an adapted version of the original AMT, in which participants are required to recall both specific and categoric memories. A specific memory is defined as an event that happened at a specific time in a certain place (e.g. ‘Winning my tennis match last Thursday’), whereas a categoric memory is defined as a memory of an event that happened on many different occasions (e.g. ‘I used to play tennis every Thursday’). Participants are presented with 24 cue words in total (8 positive, 8 negative and 8 neutral), divided into three blocks. In one block of 6 cues, participants are asked to generate specific memories, for one block of 6 cues they are asked to generate categoric memories. For one block of 12 cues, they alternate between recall of categoric and specific memories. The order of these blocks will be randomised across participants to control for order effects. 
Two lists of cue words will be randomised between participants, the original list created by Dritschel, Beltsos, McClintock, & Beltosis, (2014), and a second list created by Hitchcock et al., (2019). Both cue lists were taken from the MRC Psycholinguistic database, and have been matched for word frequency (Wilson, 1988). 
The instructions will be presented on a computer. Before completing the test trials, participants will be given four practice trials (two specific, two categoric), using neutral cue words, and feedback will be given for any incorrect answers. During the test phase, each cue will appear on the screen with an instruction indicating whether to recall a specific or categoric memory (e.g. ‘please retrieve a specific memory associated with the word ‘happy’’). Participants will be given 1 minute to respond, indicating that they have a memory in mind, and will then report the memory to the researcher aloud. Responses will be coded by the experimenter, and voice recorded for later second rating by an independent scorer. 
Items will be coded as specific, extended (lasting longer than 1 day), categoric, a repetition (a memory that had previously been reported), a semantic associate (information related to the cue, but which is not an autobiographical memory), or an omission (failure to generate a memory). For each block, the number of correct responses will be calculated. The proportion of internal and external details generated will be assessed using the Autobiographical Interview scoring procedure. Internal details consist of specific information regarding who, what, where, and when features of a specific episodic memory, whereas external details include description of related facts, elaborations, or references to other events, and are thought to draw on more general semantic processing.


Retrieval induced forgetting:

RIF will be measured using a procedure based on the original paradigm established by Anderson, Bjork, & Bjork, (1994). Participants will begin by studying 48 category–exemplar pairs (e.g., Kitchen–fork; profession– nurse) (36 critical pairs, 12 fillers). Half of the exemplars will be ‘strong’ (high frequency) exemplars of the given category (e.g. kitchen – fork), whilst the other half will be weak exemplars of the category (e.g. kitchen – mixer).  Participants will then practice retrieving the weak subset of exemplars from a subset of categories, when provided with the category cue plus the letter stem of the target exemplar (e.g., Kitchen–mi____?). Each exemplar will be practised three times each. 
Participants will take a 5-minute break, following which they will complete a final recall test. They will be cued with the category plus single letter-stem, and asked to recall the associated exemplar. The order will be controlled such that unpractised items from practiced categories (RP- items) and their baselines (NRP- items) will be cued first, followed by practiced (RP+) items and their baselines (NRP+). This is to reduce the chances of the strengthened RP+ items blocking recall of the RP- items. A single RIF score will be calculated by subtracting percentage of RP− exemplars correctly recalled from percentage of NRP exemplars correctly recalled.  Higher scores indicate greater RIF, which is thought to reflect ability to inhibit competing items during selective retrieval. 


Verbal fluency:

The Verbal Fluency Task (VFT; Spreen & Strauss, 1998) assesses executive control over verbal information.  Participants will be asked to generate as many words within a given category (animals, foods, or occupations) as they can in 60 seconds. They will then be given a further 60 s to generate as many words as they can beginning with a certain letter (F, A or S). Participants will be told that repetitions, proper nouns (e.g., France), and more than one word of the same origin (e.g., swim, swimming) will not be accepted. Verbal fluency score will be calculated as the number of correct words in each condition.


Working memory:

The Digit Span (DS) subtest of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale-IV (WAIS-IV) (Wechsler, 2008) will be administered and scored according to the test manual. Participants are read a sequence of numbers of increasing length at a rate of approximately one digit per second, and are asked to repeat the sequence back to the experimenter (DS-forward). The task is stopped when the participant reports the sequence incorrectly on two consecutive trials. This procedure is repeated, this time asking participants to report the sequence in reverse order (DS-backwards). Scores will be calculated by summing the raw forwards and backwards DS scores. 


Symptom measures:

The BDI-II consists of 21 items that assess the presence and severity of depressive symptoms over the past 2 weeks. A score of 13 or below is considered to be within the normal/nonclinical range, 14 to 19 reflects the mild range, 17 to 29 reflects the moderate range, and 30 and above reflects the severe range of symptom severity (Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996).

Ruminative tendency will be assessed using the Ruminative Response Scale (RRS) (Nolen-Hoeksema & Morrow, 1991), a 22-item questionnaire that assesses how often how often participants engage in ruminative thought patterns when they are feeling sad or down. Each item is rated on a 1 (almost never) to 4 (almost always) Likert scale. The RRS is a reliable and valid measure of rumination (Luminet, 2004), with high internal consistency (reported Cronbach’s coefficient of .91, Moberly & Watkins, 2008). Scores range from 22 to 88, with higher scores indicative of greater levels of ruminative thinking.

The intensity of dysfunctional attitudes will be measured with the Dysfunctional Attitude Scale (DAS-A-17)(de Graaf, Roelofs, & Huibers, 2009). Participants rate 17 statements on a 4-point Likert scale of how much they agree with the statement. The scale shows high internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha .91). Total score is the sum of the 17 items, with a range of 17-68. Higher scores reflect more dysfunctional attitudes.


Reappraisal scenario generation:

In Session 1, participants will generate two negative scenarios for use in the reappraisal tasks in Session 2. Participants will be instructed to recall and describe two specific scenarios to the experimenter in as much detail as they can remember; 1) an occasion when something didn’t work out as well they wanted, and 2) an occasion when a social interaction didn’t go well. If participants struggle to recall a specific event, they will be given some further prompts (e.g. ‘perhaps a time when you were disappointed in your performance’). They will be instructed not to choose major life events (e.g. marital breakdown, losing their job), but every day-type negative events. Once they have come up with an event, participants will be asked to write down their appraisal of the event (e.g. 'I never get anything right' or 'She doesn't like me'). They will then be asked to rate how much they logically believe this thought to be true and how much they feel like it is true, on a scale of 0-100. In the final section of the worksheet, participants will be asked to rate, in relation to the event, how strongly they feel each of 5 listed emotions (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious) on a scale of 0-100. This procedure will be repeated for the second event. 


Selection of assumptions:

Participants will also select two negative self-assumptions which they will challenge during the evidence gathering tasks in Session 2. They will be given a list of six statements which were selected and adapted from the Dysfunctional Attitudes Scale (DAS). The selected statements reflect core beliefs that are commonly held by people with depression, relating either to failure (e.g. 'If I cannot do something well, there is little point in doing it at all'), or inferiority (e.g. 'If other people know what you're really like, they will think less of you'). Participants will rate each statement in terms of how much they believe it to be true (logically, emotionally), and how important that assumption is to their identity.  Based on these ratings the experimenter will select one failure assumption and one inferiority assumption, matched as closely as possible for strength of belief and importance to identity. 

Cognitive reappraisal task:

Cognitive reappraisal is a technique used frequently in cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), which aims to down-regulate the negative emotions associated with a certain situation by reframing it and reinterpreting its meaning. In the current study, participants will be presented with one of the episodes that they generated in Session 1 (a time when something didn’t go as planned, or a time when a social interaction didn’t go well). Before the induction procedure, participants will be given a standardised set of instructions and an example of a completed reappraisal worksheet. Instructions will state that they should try to reframe the original meaning of the event by trying to think of alternative interpretations. Following the induction, participants will be given a blank version of the worksheet with one their previously generated negative scenarios. They will be given approximately 10 minutes to write down as many more adaptive reappraisals as they can. The worksheet includes prompts such as ‘What would another person in a similar situation think about this?’ or ‘Is what I believe the only way, or the best way to view this situation?’ They will then be asked to re-rate how strongly they believe the original event appraisal (logically, emotionally), and to re-rate the intensity of feelings (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious) about the event. This procedure will be repeated for the second event following the second induction. The event-type (poor task performance, social) will be counterbalanced across induction conditions (specificity vs control). 

Number of alternative appraisals generated by the participant will be counted by blinded scorers. To assess the change in belief in the original event appraisal as a result of the exercise, difference scores will be calculated by deducting the original belief ratings (logical and emotional) from the post-reappraisal belief ratings. More negative scores indicate a reduction in the strength of belief whereas a positive score indicates a strengthening of the belief following reappraisal. A change score will also be calculated for the rated intensity of each the 5 emotions by deducting the original ratings from the post-reappraisal ratings. Again, negative scores indicate a decrease in the strength of the feeling(s). 


Evidence gathering task:

Evidence gathering is another commonly used CBT technique, which aims to modify the maladaptive assumptions that an individual holds about themselves or the world. Once a maladpative assumption (e.g., If I fail at my work, then I am a failure as a person) is identified, the evidence for and against it can be evaluated, supporting the generation of a more functional assumption.  
In Session 2, participants will gather evidence to support an alternate assumption which counters the negative self-assumption that was selected in Session 1. Before the induction procedure, participants will be given a standardised set of instructions and an example evidence gathering worksheet.  Participants will be instructed to come up with an alternative, more helpful assumption which counters the negative self-assumption. They will be instructed to rate how much they believe this to be true (logically and emotionally, on a scale of 0-100).They will also be asked to rate, in relation to the new assumption, how strongly they feel each of 5 emotions (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious) on a scale of 0-100. 
Following the induction procedure, they will be instructed to think of some examples of situations from their personal past that would support the new, more helpful assumption. Participants will have approximately 10 minutes to come up with as many pieces of evidence as they can, writing them in the relevant section on the worksheet. Following this exercise, they will be asked to re-rate the extent to which they now believe the original and the new assumption (both logically and emotionally), and re-rate the strength of their emotions about the new assumption. This procedure will be repeated for the second negative assumption following the second induction. The assumption-type (failure, inferiority) will be counterbalanced across conditions (specificity vs control). 
Number of specific pieces of evidence will be counted by blinded scorers. Change in belief rating scores for both the original assumption and the new assumption will be calculated by deducting the original belief ratings (logical, emotional) from the post-evidence gathering belief ratings. Negative scores indicate a reduction in the strength of belief whereas a positive score indicates a strengthening of the belief following the evidence gathering task. A change score will also be calculated for the rated intensity of each of the 5 rated emotions by deducting the original ratings from the post-reappraisal ratings. Again, negative scores indicate a decrease in the strength of the feeling(s). 


Follow up worksheet:

One-week after completion of Session 2, participants will be contacted via email/phone, and asked to complete four short follow-up worksheets. The worksheets follow the same structure as the reappraisal and evidence gathering worksheets completed in Session 2. To examine the enduring effects of the reappraisal task, participants will be provided with their original negative event descriptions and original appraisal. They will be asked to write down as many of the reappraisals that they can remember generating in Session 2. They will then be asked to re-rate how much they believe the original interpretation (logically, emotionally). In the final section of the worksheet, the 5 previously rated emotions will be listed (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious), and participants will be asked to rate how strongly they now feel this way about it. This procedure will be repeated for both of the reappraisal exercises (control and specificity conditions). 
Similarly, for the follow-up evidence gathering worksheets participants will be provided with their original negative assumption, and the alternative assumption that they generated. They will be asked to write down as many of the pieces of evidence they can remember generating in Session 2 in support of the alternative assumption. They will then be asked to re-rate their strength of belief in the original assumption (logically and emotionally), and the alternative assumption (logically, emotionally). Lastly, the five previously-rated emotions will be listed and participants will be asked to rate how strongly they now feel this way about the new assumption. This will be completed for the assumptions challenged in both the specificity and control induction condition. 

The proportion of a) event reappraisals and b) pieces of evidence correctly recalled will be counted by independent scorers, who will be blinded to the experimental conditions. For both tasks, belief change scores will be calculated by deducting the original belief ratings (logical, emotional) from the follow-up belief rating scores. Negative scores indicate a reduction in the strength of belief, whereas positive scores indicate a strengthening of the belief. Similarly, a change score will be calculated for each of the 5 rated emotions by deducting the original ratings from the follow-up ratings, with more negative scores indicating a greater reduction in the emotion strength.

q13.value: Our required sample size is 30 participants. We will continue recruiting until 30 participants have completed both experimental sessions.

q14.value: A power analysis was conducted using G*Power 3 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). On the basis of the large effect of the specificity induction on a reappraisal task (d = 0.95), reported by Jing et al. (2016), with a corrected alpha value of 0.025 to control for multiple comparisons, a minimum of 20 participants will be required (power > 0.95, two-tailed, within-subjects design). For the effect of the specificity induction on belief ratings we anticipate effect sizes similar to those reported by Jing et al (2016) for the perceived likelihood of a bad outcome for a future event (d=0.74). On this basis, 30 participants will be required (power > 0.95, α=0.025, two-tailed, within subjects design).

q15.value: Data collection will stop when all 30 participants have completed both experimental sessions.

question.value:
Specificity vs control induction. 
The (a) reappraisal and b) evidence gathering exercises will be completed following the i) control induction and ii) the specificity induction (counterbalanced order). The inductions will be conducted in the same manner as previous studies (e.g. Jing et al., 2016; 2017; Madore et al., 2014). Both induction-types involve watching a 2 minute video clip of adults performing routine activities, and then answering questions about the video. In the control induction, the questions ask participants for their general impressions about the video (e.g., whether they liked it, the techniques used to make the video). In the specificity induction, the questions ask participants to provide specific detail regarding the people, actions, and surroundings in the video, using mental imagery probes. Total questioning time for the initial inductions will be six minutes. The brief top-up inductions completed between tasks will follow the same procedure as the initial inductions, but with a shorter, three minute questioning period. Four different video clips will be used, with a different video for each induction, counterbalanced across task and induction-type.

Dependent variables
Reappraisal task: 
1.	Number of specific alternative interpretations generated.
2.	Change in strength of belief in the negative appraisal of the event (post- reappraisal belief rating minus original belief rating), in terms of 
i.	How much they logically believe it to be true (logical belief rating)
ii.	How much it feels true (emotional belief rating). 
3.	Change in rated intensity of emotions about the event (post-reappraisal rating(s) minus original rating(s)).
4.	Participant-rated task difficulty. 
5.	Participant-rated task helpfulness. 
6.	Number of specific alternative interpretations recalled at 1-week delay.
7.	Endurance in change in strength of belief (for both logical and emotional ratings) in the negative appraisal after a 1-week delay (rating at 1-week delay minus original rating). 

Evidence gathering task: 
1.	Number of specific pieces of evidence generated in support of the alternate, more adaptive assumption.
2.	Change in strength of belief in the original maladaptive assumption of the event (post- reappraisal belief rating minus original belief rating), in terms of 
i.	How much they logically believe it to be true (logical belief rating)
ii.	How much it feels true (emotional belief rating).
3.	Change in strength of belief in the new, adaptive assumption of the event (post- reappraisal belief rating minus original belief rating), in terms of 
i.	How much they logically believe it to be true (logical belief rating)
ii.	How much it feels true (emotional belief rating).
4.	Change in rated intensity of emotions about the event (post-reappraisal rating(s) minus original rating(s). 
5.	Participant-rated task difficulty. 
6.	Participant-rated task helpfulness. 
7.	Number of specific pieces of evidence recalled at a 1-week delay.
8.	Endurance in change in strength of belief (for both logical and emotional ratings) in the maladaptive assumption after a 1-week delay (rating at 1-week delay minus original rating). 

Variables acting as covariates or moderators.  
1.	Amount of CBT previously completed (approximate number of sessions).
2.	Depressive symptom severity (BDI-II score). 
3.	Working memory capacity indexed by score on Digit Span Test.
4.	Verbal fluency – number of correct words generated on the Verbal Fluency Task.  
5.	Retrieval induced forgetting score.

Change in belief will be reversed score, such that a positive value indicates an increase in belief rating from pre-induction, and a negative value indicates a reduction in belief rating from pre-induction.

Primary outcomes:

Hypothesis 1a will be tested using paired t-tests to compare the number of alternative interpretations generated in the reappraisal task following the specificity vs control induction.

Hypothesis 1b will be tested using a repeated measures ANOVA, with the within-subjects factors of the induction type (control, specificity) and change in strength of belief in the original appraisal (emotional, logical).
 
Hypothesis 2a will be tested using paired t-tests to compare the number of specific pieces of evidence generated during the evidence gathering task that followed the specificity induction, relative to the control induction.

Hypothesis 2b will be tested using a repeated measures ANOVA, with the within-subjects factors of induction type (control, specificity) and change in strength of belief in the new (alternate) assumption (emotional, logical).


Secondary outcomes:

Hypothesis 3: For the evidence gathering task, we will examine the change in the strength of belief in the original assumption using a repeated measures ANOVA. The within-subjects factors will include induction type (control, specificity) and change in belief rating (emotional belief, logical belief).  

Hypothesis 4: To examine the longer-term impact of the tasks completed following the specificity induction, relative to the control induction, we will examine (i) the proportion of alternate appraisals and (ii) the proportion of pieces of evidence generated in Session 2 that can be recalled at a 1-week delay. Paired t-tests will be used to compare the specificity and control induction conditions. We will also calculate the difference in strength of belief (both emotional and logical) at 1 week vs before completing the exercise. Difference scores will be compared using repeated measures ANOVAs with the within subjects factors of induction (specificity, control) and belief type (emotional, logical), for both the reappraisal and evidence gathering tasks.

q21.value: We will apply a Bonferroni correction to correct for the multiple comparisons for the primary analyses per task (adjusted alpha value of 0.025, as used for power analysis

q23.value: Participants who complete Session 1, but do not return to complete Session 2 will be excluded, and we will continue recruiting until a total of 30 participants have completed both sessions. As a result, we do not anticipate having much missing data for the tasks completed in the experimental sessions themselves. However, any data that is missing will be handled using multiple imputation.

Two separate one-way MANOVAs will be conducted (one per task), with induction type (specificity, control) as the independent variable, and change in the rated intensity of each of the 5 emotions as the dependent variables. 

2.	We will use paired t-tests to examine whether the a) reappraisal and b) evidence gathering tasks completed in the specificity induction condition are rated as having been less difficult than those completed in the control induction condition. 

3.	We will use paired t-tests to examine whether the a) reappraisal and b) evidence gathering tasks completed in the specificity induction condition are rated as having been more helpful than those completed in the control induction condition. 

4.	To explore whether baseline executive function, memory flexibility, depressive symptom severity or CBT experience moderate the effects of the specificity induction, we will follow the approach recommended by Judd, Kenny, & McClelland, (2001) for moderation analyses in repeated measures designs. This involves calculating  specificity vs control induction difference scores for each of the outcome measures (number of specific alternative interpretations, number of specific pieces of evidence, belief change ratings (reappraisal), belief change ratings (evidence gathering). Multiple regression analyses will be used to determine whether these differences are predicted by the moderator variables.

registration_responses.q1: Transient autobiographical memory enhancement to improve the efficacy of CBT tasks.
registration_responses.q3:
Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is currently the gold-standard treatment for depression. CBT techniques draw upon an individual’s autobiographical memory for their personal past, and require the individual to imagine future events, with the aim of changing the negative beliefs and assumptions that underpin dysfunctional models of the self and the world. Many of the core elements of CBT rely on cognitive processes (e.g., cognitive reappraisal, problem solving) that depend on the ability to recall specific, autobiographical information. For example, a commonly-used CBT technique involves asking an individual to evaluate the validity of a maladaptive assumption or belief (e.g., I am a total failure) by gathering specific information from their past which may act as evidence against the belief (e.g., I made a tasty dinner last week). Autobiographical memory processes are commonly disrupted in depression. People with depression show a chronic bias towards retrieving generalised summaries about the personal past, rather than memories for specific, single episodes (Dalgleish et al., 2007; Sumner, 2012; Williams et al., 2007). These biases towards overgeneralised memory retrieval, and away from recall of specific information, may thereby impair the ability to engage with, and benefit from CBT. 

Recent work has shown that inducing a more specific processing style can temporarily help people to become more specific in their memory retrieval, and enhance performance on tasks that draw upon episodic memory processes (Jing, Madore, & Schacter, 2016, 2017; Madore & Schacter, 2014; Sheldon, Gurguryan, Madore, & Schacter, 2019). Jing et al. (2016) found that an episodic specificity induction – brief training in recollecting specific details of a recent experience - enhanced problem solving and episodic reappraisal within a healthy student population. Within a depressed population, McFarland, Primosch, Maxson, & Stewart, (2017) found that the same specificity induction procedure improved performance on a subsequent problem solving task.

The current study will investigate whether a similar specificity induction procedure can help depressed individuals complete CBT exercises that rely on specific autobiographical retrieval, and whether this improves the efficacy of the CBT exercises. We will examine whether, relative to a control (general impressions about an event) induction procedure, the episodic specificity induction a) enhances the number of specific alternative interpretations generated on an episodic reappraisal task, and b) increases the number of pieces of evidence gathered in an exercise designed to evaluate the validity of a negative self-assumption (evidence gathering task). We will examine whether there is a corresponding change in strength of belief ratings (both how much it is logically believed to be true, and how much it feels true) for the challenged interpretations and assumptions. We will also explore the endurance of these effects, and possible moderating factors.
registration_responses.q4:
Primary hypotheses:
1)	On the reappraisal task, we anticipate that 
a)	Participants will generate a greater number, on average, of alternate interpretations following the specificity induction, compared with the control induction condition. 
b)	As a result of this, we anticipate a greater decrease in both logical and emotional belief ratings for the original negative appraisal for the event reappraised in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control condition.  
2)	On the evidence gathering task, we predict that
a)	A greater number of pieces of evidence will be generated following the specificity induction, relative to the control induction condition. 
b)	There will be a greater increase in strength of belief (logical, emotional) in the new, alternative assumption following the evidence gathering task completed in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition.
Secondary hypotheses:   

3)	For the evidence gathering task, we predict that there will be a greater decrease in strength of belief ratings for the original assumption in the specificity induction condition than the control condition.   

4)	Following a 1-week delay, we predict that a greater proportion of the generated a) alternative interpretations and b) pieces of evidence, will be recalled for the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition. We anticipate that this will be reflected in the strength of belief ratings, such that the change in belief ratings following each exercise endures to a greater extent for a) events reappraised and b) evidence gathered following the specificity induction compared with the control induction. 

Exploratory:

1)	We will explore whether initial feelings about the events and assumptions change to a greater extent in the specificity induction condition than the control condition. 
a)	For the reappraisal task, we will explore whether the rated intensity of feelings about the event changes to a greater extent in the specificity induction condition than in the control induction condition. 
b)	For the evidence gathering task, we will explore whether the rated intensity of feelings about the new, alternate assumption changes to a greater extent in the specificity induction condition than the control condition. 

2)	We will explore whether participants rate the a) reappraisal task and b) evidence gathering task as less difficult in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition. 

3)	We will explore whether participants rate the a) reappraisal task and b) evidence gathering task as more helpful in the specificity induction condition, relative to the control induction condition. 

4)	We will explore whether the effect of the specificity induction is moderated by factors including baseline executive function (verbal fluency, working memory, inhibitory control over memory), memory flexibility (AMT-AI score), previous completion of CBT, and depression symptom severity (BDI-II). Induction order effects (e.g., specificity first vs control first) will also be evaluated.

registration_responses.q14: A power analysis was conducted using G*Power 3 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). On the basis of the large effect of the specificity induction on a reappraisal task (d = 0.95), reported by Jing et al. (2016), with a corrected alpha value of 0.025 to control for multiple comparisons, a minimum of 20 participants will be required (power > 0.95, two-tailed, within-subjects design). For the effect of the specificity induction on belief ratings we anticipate effect sizes similar to those reported by Jing et al (2016) for the perceived likelihood of a bad outcome for a future event (d=0.74). On this basis, 30 participants will be required (power > 0.95, α=0.025, two-tailed, within subjects design).

registration_responses.q8.question: Within-subjects repeated measures experiment in which all participants will complete both the a) reappraisal and b) evidence gathering tasks following each induction type (specificity induction, impressions control). The order of the induction type will be counterbalanced across induction conditions. The order of the CBT tasks will be fixed (reappraisal then evidence gathering) as, based on our clinical experience, it is likely that completing evidence gathering first would have strong effects on later completion of a reappraisal task.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants aged 18-70 who meet criteria for a current diagnosis of Major Depressive Disorder will be recruited from the MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit clinical volunteer panel. Depression status will be confirmed using the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 (First, Williams, Karg, & Spitzer, 2015). Exclusion criteria include any intellectual disability, past or present neurological disorder, and current substance or alcohol dependence. Any participants who show severe impairments on executive tests in session 1 will be excluded from the study. 

Procedure 
 
The study will be completed in two 60-90 minute sessions, completed on two separate days. During Session 1, participants will complete the memory and executive function tests; the Alternating Instructions version of the Autobiographical Memory Test (AMT-AI) , a retrieval-induced forgetting test, the Verbal Fluency Task and the Digit Span Test of working memory. Questionnaire measures of depressive symptoms (Beck’s Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II)), ruminative tendency (Ruminative Response Scale (RRS)) and dysfunctional attitudes (Dysfunctional Attitudes Scale (DAS)) will also be administered. Finally, participants will select two maladaptive assumptions and generate memories of two negative scenarios (a negative social interaction, and a time when something didn't go as planned) for use in the CBT tasks in Session 2. 

In Session 2, participants will complete an induction (specificity or control) followed by the reappraisal task, a short top-up induction, and the evidence gathering task. The procedure will then be completed with the alternate (specificity or control) induction. The order of the induction type (specificity, impressions control) will be counterbalanced. Both induction procedures involve watching a two minute video clip of individuals completing everyday activities (e.g., cooking, morning routine), and answering questions about the video. A different video will be used for each induction, and videos will be counterbalanced across task (evidence gathering, reappraisal) and induction-type. The reappraisal scenario type (negative social interaction, and a time when something didn't go as planned), and the nature of the assumption (failure, inferiority) selected for evidence gathering will be counterbalanced across induction conditions. 

One week after Session 2, participants will be contacted by telephone and/or email and asked to complete a follow-up worksheet designed to assess the endurance of the experimental effects. 


Materials and method:


Autobiographical memory test (alternating instructions):

The AMT is designed to measure ability to deliberately retrieve specific memories in response to a series of positive, negative and neutrally valenced cue words (Williams & Broadbent, 1986).  The alternating instructions AMT (AMT-AI) is an adapted version of the original AMT, in which participants are required to recall both specific and categoric memories. A specific memory is defined as an event that happened at a specific time in a certain place (e.g. ‘Winning my tennis match last Thursday’), whereas a categoric memory is defined as a memory of an event that happened on many different occasions (e.g. ‘I used to play tennis every Thursday’). Participants are presented with 24 cue words in total (8 positive, 8 negative and 8 neutral), divided into three blocks. In one block of 6 cues, participants are asked to generate specific memories, for one block of 6 cues they are asked to generate categoric memories. For one block of 12 cues, they alternate between recall of categoric and specific memories. The order of these blocks will be randomised across participants to control for order effects. 
Two lists of cue words will be randomised between participants, the original list created by Dritschel, Beltsos, McClintock, & Beltosis, (2014), and a second list created by Hitchcock et al., (2019). Both cue lists were taken from the MRC Psycholinguistic database, and have been matched for word frequency (Wilson, 1988). 
The instructions will be presented on a computer. Before completing the test trials, participants will be given four practice trials (two specific, two categoric), using neutral cue words, and feedback will be given for any incorrect answers. During the test phase, each cue will appear on the screen with an instruction indicating whether to recall a specific or categoric memory (e.g. ‘please retrieve a specific memory associated with the word ‘happy’’). Participants will be given 1 minute to respond, indicating that they have a memory in mind, and will then report the memory to the researcher aloud. Responses will be coded by the experimenter, and voice recorded for later second rating by an independent scorer. 
Items will be coded as specific, extended (lasting longer than 1 day), categoric, a repetition (a memory that had previously been reported), a semantic associate (information related to the cue, but which is not an autobiographical memory), or an omission (failure to generate a memory). For each block, the number of correct responses will be calculated. The proportion of internal and external details generated will be assessed using the Autobiographical Interview scoring procedure. Internal details consist of specific information regarding who, what, where, and when features of a specific episodic memory, whereas external details include description of related facts, elaborations, or references to other events, and are thought to draw on more general semantic processing.


Retrieval induced forgetting:

RIF will be measured using a procedure based on the original paradigm established by Anderson, Bjork, & Bjork, (1994). Participants will begin by studying 48 category–exemplar pairs (e.g., Kitchen–fork; profession– nurse) (36 critical pairs, 12 fillers). Half of the exemplars will be ‘strong’ (high frequency) exemplars of the given category (e.g. kitchen – fork), whilst the other half will be weak exemplars of the category (e.g. kitchen – mixer).  Participants will then practice retrieving the weak subset of exemplars from a subset of categories, when provided with the category cue plus the letter stem of the target exemplar (e.g., Kitchen–mi____?). Each exemplar will be practised three times each. 
Participants will take a 5-minute break, following which they will complete a final recall test. They will be cued with the category plus single letter-stem, and asked to recall the associated exemplar. The order will be controlled such that unpractised items from practiced categories (RP- items) and their baselines (NRP- items) will be cued first, followed by practiced (RP+) items and their baselines (NRP+). This is to reduce the chances of the strengthened RP+ items blocking recall of the RP- items. A single RIF score will be calculated by subtracting percentage of RP− exemplars correctly recalled from percentage of NRP exemplars correctly recalled.  Higher scores indicate greater RIF, which is thought to reflect ability to inhibit competing items during selective retrieval. 


Verbal fluency:

The Verbal Fluency Task (VFT; Spreen & Strauss, 1998) assesses executive control over verbal information.  Participants will be asked to generate as many words within a given category (animals, foods, or occupations) as they can in 60 seconds. They will then be given a further 60 s to generate as many words as they can beginning with a certain letter (F, A or S). Participants will be told that repetitions, proper nouns (e.g., France), and more than one word of the same origin (e.g., swim, swimming) will not be accepted. Verbal fluency score will be calculated as the number of correct words in each condition.


Working memory:

The Digit Span (DS) subtest of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale-IV (WAIS-IV) (Wechsler, 2008) will be administered and scored according to the test manual. Participants are read a sequence of numbers of increasing length at a rate of approximately one digit per second, and are asked to repeat the sequence back to the experimenter (DS-forward). The task is stopped when the participant reports the sequence incorrectly on two consecutive trials. This procedure is repeated, this time asking participants to report the sequence in reverse order (DS-backwards). Scores will be calculated by summing the raw forwards and backwards DS scores. 


Symptom measures:

The BDI-II consists of 21 items that assess the presence and severity of depressive symptoms over the past 2 weeks. A score of 13 or below is considered to be within the normal/nonclinical range, 14 to 19 reflects the mild range, 17 to 29 reflects the moderate range, and 30 and above reflects the severe range of symptom severity (Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996).

Ruminative tendency will be assessed using the Ruminative Response Scale (RRS) (Nolen-Hoeksema & Morrow, 1991), a 22-item questionnaire that assesses how often how often participants engage in ruminative thought patterns when they are feeling sad or down. Each item is rated on a 1 (almost never) to 4 (almost always) Likert scale. The RRS is a reliable and valid measure of rumination (Luminet, 2004), with high internal consistency (reported Cronbach’s coefficient of .91, Moberly & Watkins, 2008). Scores range from 22 to 88, with higher scores indicative of greater levels of ruminative thinking.

The intensity of dysfunctional attitudes will be measured with the Dysfunctional Attitude Scale (DAS-A-17)(de Graaf, Roelofs, & Huibers, 2009). Participants rate 17 statements on a 4-point Likert scale of how much they agree with the statement. The scale shows high internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha .91). Total score is the sum of the 17 items, with a range of 17-68. Higher scores reflect more dysfunctional attitudes.


Reappraisal scenario generation:

In Session 1, participants will generate two negative scenarios for use in the reappraisal tasks in Session 2. Participants will be instructed to recall and describe two specific scenarios to the experimenter in as much detail as they can remember; 1) an occasion when something didn’t work out as well they wanted, and 2) an occasion when a social interaction didn’t go well. If participants struggle to recall a specific event, they will be given some further prompts (e.g. ‘perhaps a time when you were disappointed in your performance’). They will be instructed not to choose major life events (e.g. marital breakdown, losing their job), but every day-type negative events. Once they have come up with an event, participants will be asked to write down their appraisal of the event (e.g. 'I never get anything right' or 'She doesn't like me'). They will then be asked to rate how much they logically believe this thought to be true and how much they feel like it is true, on a scale of 0-100. In the final section of the worksheet, participants will be asked to rate, in relation to the event, how strongly they feel each of 5 listed emotions (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious) on a scale of 0-100. This procedure will be repeated for the second event. 


Selection of assumptions:

Participants will also select two negative self-assumptions which they will challenge during the evidence gathering tasks in Session 2. They will be given a list of six statements which were selected and adapted from the Dysfunctional Attitudes Scale (DAS). The selected statements reflect core beliefs that are commonly held by people with depression, relating either to failure (e.g. 'If I cannot do something well, there is little point in doing it at all'), or inferiority (e.g. 'If other people know what you're really like, they will think less of you'). Participants will rate each statement in terms of how much they believe it to be true (logically, emotionally), and how important that assumption is to their identity.  Based on these ratings the experimenter will select one failure assumption and one inferiority assumption, matched as closely as possible for strength of belief and importance to identity. 

Cognitive reappraisal task:

Cognitive reappraisal is a technique used frequently in cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), which aims to down-regulate the negative emotions associated with a certain situation by reframing it and reinterpreting its meaning. In the current study, participants will be presented with one of the episodes that they generated in Session 1 (a time when something didn’t go as planned, or a time when a social interaction didn’t go well). Before the induction procedure, participants will be given a standardised set of instructions and an example of a completed reappraisal worksheet. Instructions will state that they should try to reframe the original meaning of the event by trying to think of alternative interpretations. Following the induction, participants will be given a blank version of the worksheet with one their previously generated negative scenarios. They will be given approximately 10 minutes to write down as many more adaptive reappraisals as they can. The worksheet includes prompts such as ‘What would another person in a similar situation think about this?’ or ‘Is what I believe the only way, or the best way to view this situation?’ They will then be asked to re-rate how strongly they believe the original event appraisal (logically, emotionally), and to re-rate the intensity of feelings (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious) about the event. This procedure will be repeated for the second event following the second induction. The event-type (poor task performance, social) will be counterbalanced across induction conditions (specificity vs control). 

Number of alternative appraisals generated by the participant will be counted by blinded scorers. To assess the change in belief in the original event appraisal as a result of the exercise, difference scores will be calculated by deducting the original belief ratings (logical and emotional) from the post-reappraisal belief ratings. More negative scores indicate a reduction in the strength of belief whereas a positive score indicates a strengthening of the belief following reappraisal. A change score will also be calculated for the rated intensity of each the 5 emotions by deducting the original ratings from the post-reappraisal ratings. Again, negative scores indicate a decrease in the strength of the feeling(s). 


Evidence gathering task:

Evidence gathering is another commonly used CBT technique, which aims to modify the maladaptive assumptions that an individual holds about themselves or the world. Once a maladpative assumption (e.g., If I fail at my work, then I am a failure as a person) is identified, the evidence for and against it can be evaluated, supporting the generation of a more functional assumption.  
In Session 2, participants will gather evidence to support an alternate assumption which counters the negative self-assumption that was selected in Session 1. Before the induction procedure, participants will be given a standardised set of instructions and an example evidence gathering worksheet.  Participants will be instructed to come up with an alternative, more helpful assumption which counters the negative self-assumption. They will be instructed to rate how much they believe this to be true (logically and emotionally, on a scale of 0-100).They will also be asked to rate, in relation to the new assumption, how strongly they feel each of 5 emotions (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious) on a scale of 0-100. 
Following the induction procedure, they will be instructed to think of some examples of situations from their personal past that would support the new, more helpful assumption. Participants will have approximately 10 minutes to come up with as many pieces of evidence as they can, writing them in the relevant section on the worksheet. Following this exercise, they will be asked to re-rate the extent to which they now believe the original and the new assumption (both logically and emotionally), and re-rate the strength of their emotions about the new assumption. This procedure will be repeated for the second negative assumption following the second induction. The assumption-type (failure, inferiority) will be counterbalanced across conditions (specificity vs control). 
Number of specific pieces of evidence will be counted by blinded scorers. Change in belief rating scores for both the original assumption and the new assumption will be calculated by deducting the original belief ratings (logical, emotional) from the post-evidence gathering belief ratings. Negative scores indicate a reduction in the strength of belief whereas a positive score indicates a strengthening of the belief following the evidence gathering task. A change score will also be calculated for the rated intensity of each of the 5 rated emotions by deducting the original ratings from the post-reappraisal ratings. Again, negative scores indicate a decrease in the strength of the feeling(s). 


Follow up worksheet:

One-week after completion of Session 2, participants will be contacted via email/phone, and asked to complete four short follow-up worksheets. The worksheets follow the same structure as the reappraisal and evidence gathering worksheets completed in Session 2. To examine the enduring effects of the reappraisal task, participants will be provided with their original negative event descriptions and original appraisal. They will be asked to write down as many of the reappraisals that they can remember generating in Session 2. They will then be asked to re-rate how much they believe the original interpretation (logically, emotionally). In the final section of the worksheet, the 5 previously rated emotions will be listed (satisfied, sad, hopeful, guilty, anxious), and participants will be asked to rate how strongly they now feel this way about it. This procedure will be repeated for both of the reappraisal exercises (control and specificity conditions). 
Similarly, for the follow-up evidence gathering worksheets participants will be provided with their original negative assumption, and the alternative assumption that they generated. They will be asked to write down as many of the pieces of evidence they can remember generating in Session 2 in support of the alternative assumption. They will then be asked to re-rate their strength of belief in the original assumption (logically and emotionally), and the alternative assumption (logically, emotionally). Lastly, the five previously-rated emotions will be listed and participants will be asked to rate how strongly they now feel this way about the new assumption. This will be completed for the assumptions challenged in both the specificity and control induction condition. 

The proportion of a) event reappraisals and b) pieces of evidence correctly recalled will be counted by independent scorers, who will be blinded to the experimental conditions. For both tasks, belief change scores will be calculated by deducting the original belief ratings (logical, emotional) from the follow-up belief rating scores. Negative scores indicate a reduction in the strength of belief, whereas positive scores indicate a strengthening of the belief. Similarly, a change score will be calculated for each of the 5 rated emotions by deducting the original ratings from the follow-up ratings, with more negative scores indicating a greater reduction in the emotion strength.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Specificity vs control induction. 
The (a) reappraisal and b) evidence gathering exercises will be completed following the i) control induction and ii) the specificity induction (counterbalanced order). The inductions will be conducted in the same manner as previous studies (e.g. Jing et al., 2016; 2017; Madore et al., 2014). Both induction-types involve watching a 2 minute video clip of adults performing routine activities, and then answering questions about the video. In the control induction, the questions ask participants for their general impressions about the video (e.g., whether they liked it, the techniques used to make the video). In the specificity induction, the questions ask participants to provide specific detail regarding the people, actions, and surroundings in the video, using mental imagery probes. Total questioning time for the initial inductions will be six minutes. The brief top-up inductions completed between tasks will follow the same procedure as the initial inductions, but with a shorter, three minute questioning period. Four different video clips will be used, with a different video for each induction, counterbalanced across task and induction-type.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Dependent variables
Reappraisal task: 
1.	Number of specific alternative interpretations generated.
2.	Change in strength of belief in the negative appraisal of the event (post- reappraisal belief rating minus original belief rating), in terms of 
i.	How much they logically believe it to be true (logical belief rating)
ii.	How much it feels true (emotional belief rating). 
3.	Change in rated intensity of emotions about the event (post-reappraisal rating(s) minus original rating(s)).
4.	Participant-rated task difficulty. 
5.	Participant-rated task helpfulness. 
6.	Number of specific alternative interpretations recalled at 1-week delay.
7.	Endurance in change in strength of belief (for both logical and emotional ratings) in the negative appraisal after a 1-week delay (rating at 1-week delay minus original rating). 

Evidence gathering task: 
1.	Number of specific pieces of evidence generated in support of the alternate, more adaptive assumption.
2.	Change in strength of belief in the original maladaptive assumption of the event (post- reappraisal belief rating minus original belief rating), in terms of 
i.	How much they logically believe it to be true (logical belief rating)
ii.	How much it feels true (emotional belief rating).
3.	Change in strength of belief in the new, adaptive assumption of the event (post- reappraisal belief rating minus original belief rating), in terms of 
i.	How much they logically believe it to be true (logical belief rating)
ii.	How much it feels true (emotional belief rating).
4.	Change in rated intensity of emotions about the event (post-reappraisal rating(s) minus original rating(s). 
5.	Participant-rated task difficulty. 
6.	Participant-rated task helpfulness. 
7.	Number of specific pieces of evidence recalled at a 1-week delay.
8.	Endurance in change in strength of belief (for both logical and emotional ratings) in the maladaptive assumption after a 1-week delay (rating at 1-week delay minus original rating). 

Variables acting as covariates or moderators.  
1.	Amount of CBT previously completed (approximate number of sessions).
2.	Depressive symptom severity (BDI-II score). 
3.	Working memory capacity indexed by score on Digit Span Test.
4.	Verbal fluency – number of correct words generated on the Verbal Fluency Task.  
5.	Retrieval induced forgetting score.
registration_responses.q18.question: Change in belief will be reversed score, such that a positive value indicates an increase in belief rating from pre-induction, and a negative value indicates a reduction in belief rating from pre-induction.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Primary outcomes:

Hypothesis 1a will be tested using paired t-tests to compare the number of alternative interpretations generated in the reappraisal task following the specificity vs control induction.

Hypothesis 1b will be tested using a repeated measures ANOVA, with the within-subjects factors of the induction type (control, specificity) and change in strength of belief in the original appraisal (emotional, logical).
 
Hypothesis 2a will be tested using paired t-tests to compare the number of specific pieces of evidence generated during the evidence gathering task that followed the specificity induction, relative to the control induction.

Hypothesis 2b will be tested using a repeated measures ANOVA, with the within-subjects factors of induction type (control, specificity) and change in strength of belief in the new (alternate) assumption (emotional, logical).


Secondary outcomes:

Hypothesis 3: For the evidence gathering task, we will examine the change in the strength of belief in the original assumption using a repeated measures ANOVA. The within-subjects factors will include induction type (control, specificity) and change in belief rating (emotional belief, logical belief).  

Hypothesis 4: To examine the longer-term impact of the tasks completed following the specificity induction, relative to the control induction, we will examine (i) the proportion of alternate appraisals and (ii) the proportion of pieces of evidence generated in Session 2 that can be recalled at a 1-week delay. Paired t-tests will be used to compare the specificity and control induction conditions. We will also calculate the difference in strength of belief (both emotional and logical) at 1 week vs before completing the exercise. Difference scores will be compared using repeated measures ANOVAs with the within subjects factors of induction (specificity, control) and belief type (emotional, logical), for both the reappraisal and evidence gathering tasks.

attributes.title: OpenTCC: An open source low-cost temperature-controlled chamber
attributes.description:
This project includes the list of components, design schematics and code to build and run your own open source temperature controlled chamber. 
OpenTCC is an element of laboratory infrastructure that can find its use for different temperature controlled experiments but was specifically designed to be used for microbial electrochemical technologies.
