attributes.title: Does variation in methodological quality explain the discordant conclusions of meta-analyses comparing operative and non-operative treatments for proximal humeral fractures in the elderly?: a systematic review

summary.value:
Does variation in methodological quality explain the discordant conclusions of meta-analyses comparing operative and non-operative treatments for proximal humeral fractures in the elderly?: a systematic review protocol
Nicolai Sandau BSc MD1, Peter Buxbom MD PhD1, Ian Harris MBBS MMed(Clin Epi) PhD2, Asbjørn Hróbjartsson MD PhD3, Stig Brorson MD PhD DMSc1
1Centre for Evidence-Based Orthopedics, Department of Orthopedic Surgery, Zealand University Hospital, Køge, Denmark 
2Whitlam Orthopaedic Research Centre, Ingham Institute for Applied Medical Research, South Western Sydney Clinical School, SWSLHD, University of New South Wales (UNSW Sydney), Liverpool, NSW, 2170, Australia
3Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine Odense (CEBMO), University of Southern Denmark and Odense University Hospital, Odense, Denmark

Introduction
Proximal humeral fractures (PHF) are the third most common non-vertebral osteoporotic fractures among the elderly (Calvo et al., 2011; Court-Brown et al., 2017; Launonen et al., 2015). Palvanen et al. reported an average increase of 13.7% per year between 1970 and 2002 of patients older than 60 hospitalized with PHF (Palvanen et al., 2006). In a more recent study by Launonen et al. the authors reported an incidence of 379 PHF per 100,000 person-years for women and 232 per 100,000 person-years for men over the age of 80 years (Launonen et al., 2015). Both operative and non-operative interventions have been used as methods of treatment. Non-operative treatment often constitutes a period of immobilization in a sling combined with either immediate passive mobilization or delayed passive and active exercises after a period of immobilization. Multiple surgical treatment options exist, including closed reduction and percutaneous pinning, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with either plate and screws, tension-band or intramedullary fixation. Complex fractures like head-splitting fractures, fracture dislocations, and some 4-part fractures have been treated surgically with hemi-arthroplasty (HA). However, the use of reverse shoulder arthroplasty (RSA) in the primary treatment of these fractures has been increasing. Klug et al. reported a more than eightfold increase in the use of RSA for the treatment of PHF in Germany between 2007 and 2016 while the use of HA decreased by 57.1%. Locking plate fixation was used as the primary treatment in 48.3% of cases making it most used treatment of choice(Klug et al., 2019). However, no consensus on the optimal treatment modality for the primary care of PHF exist. 

Several randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have compared the functional outcome following operative or non-operative treatments for PHF (Boons et al., 2012; Fjalestad et al., 2012, 2010; Fjalestad and Hole, 2014; Handoll et al., 2017; Launonen et al., 2019; Lopiz et al., 2019; Olerud et al., 2011a, 2011b; Rangan et al., 2015; Stableforth, 1984; Zyto et al., 1997). Based on these studies several meta-analyses have been conducted to summarize the available evidence. However, the conclusions have been conflicting. A preliminary search identified 15 overlapping meta-analyses of the difference in clinical outcome between operative and non-operative treatments for PHF. Of these, 11 reported no significant difference in functional outcome measures between operative and non-operative treatments (Beks et al., 2018; Fu et al., 2014; Handoll and Brorson, 2015; Jia et al., 2014; Li et al., 2016, 2013; Mao et al., 2015, 2014; Navarro et al., 2018; Rabi, 2015; Song et al., 2015; Xie et al., 2015). Although Mao et al. (2015) reported no significant difference in functional outcome they did, however, report that patients treated operatively reported significantly higher post-operative quality of life scores compared to patients treated non-operatively. 

Three of the 15 identified meta-analyses reported a significant improvement in functional outcome for the operative intervention when compared to non-operative treatments (Chen et al., 2016; Du et al., 2017; Sabharwal et al., 2016). In the study by Sabharwal et al., the authors conducted subgroup analyses based on fracture complexity and reported that 4-part fractures managed operatively had significantly higher quality of life scores at 24 months. However, they did not report any significant difference in functional outcome between operative and non-operative treatment (Sabharwal et al., 2016). Both Chen et al. and Du et al. conducted network meta-analyses and reported that RSA was associated with the highest probability for improving functional outcome compared to other operative interventions and non-operative treatment (Chen et al., 2016; Du et al., 2017). 

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses are often used to summarize the current evidence on treatment effects and are often used by decision-makers to guide clinical practice (Mulrow, 1994). It has previously been reported that differences in methodological quality potentially can affect the outcome of meta-analyses thereby leading to conflicting conclusions (Higgins and Green, 2011; Simunovic et al., 2009). One could, therefore, hypothesize that the discordant conclusions described above are in part caused by variation in methodological quality. 

The primary aim of this study is, therefore, to investigate if variation in methodological quality can explain the discordant conclusions of systematic reviews with meta-analyses comparing operative versus non-operative treatment for proximal humeral fractures in the elderly.

Methods
The present study protocol was developed in accordance with Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis Protocols (PRISMA-P) (Moher et al., 2015). 
Eligibility criteria
Systematic reviews reporting meta-analyses comparing operative and non-operative treatments for PHF will be included. 
Systematic reviews including studies on patients below the mean age of 60 or studies on pathological fractures will be excluded. Systematic reviews that do not perform any meta-analyses will be excluded. If we identify duplicate publications or updates of the same review, we will only include the newest version as defined by publication date. No limits on publication date or language will be set.
Information sources
PubMed, EMBASE, The Cochrane Library and Web of Science will be searched using the strategy described below. Furthermore, the references of the included studies and of relevant studies identified during the selection process will be screened for potentially eligible studies. 

Search strategy
The search strategy will be developed for PubMed and will be adapted for the other bibliographic databases. 

Study records

Data management 
The retrieved records will be imported to an EndNote X9 database. Duplicates will be identified manually using EndNote’s built-in functions. The remaining records will then be uploaded to the Covidence website for the selection process (Covidence systematic review software, Veritas Health Innovation, Melbourne, Australia. Available at www.covidence.org, n.d.).

Selection process
The abstract and full text screening of potentially eligible studies will be performed independently by the first and second author. Disagreements will be solved by consensus.

Data collection process
A data extraction form will be created using Excel and piloted by the first and second author on three studies randomly selected from the included studies. After any corrections are made following the piloting process, all studies will then be extracted independently by the first and second author. Disagreements will be solved by consensus.

Data items
The following variables on study characteristics will be extracted: 
•	publication year
•	language
•	rationale for repeating review
•	PICO
•	databases searched
•	years covered in search
•	included trials
•	number of patients 
The conclusions will be grouped and classified based on outcome as follows; 1) quality of life, 2) functional outcome and 3) harm of intervention. The conclusions will be scored on a scale from 1 to 6 as described by Als-Nielsen et al. (Als-Nielsen et al., 2003). Intervention will be defined as operative treatment and control will be defined as non-operative treatment.

The methodological quality of the included studies will be evaluated using the Assessment of Multiple Systematic Reviews 2 (AMSTAR2) tool (Shea et al., 2017). AMSTAR2 is an updated version of the original AMSTAR, which is a validated tool for assessing the methodological quality of systematic reviews(Shea et al., 2009, 2007). The tool consists of 16 items evaluating the methodological quality of different steps during the process of conducting a meta-analysis. Item 1,3,5,6 and 10-16 will be scored as either ‘yes’ or ‘no’. Item 2, 4 and 7-9 will be scored as either ‘yes’, ‘partial yes’ or ‘no’. Each study will be assigned an overall rating of either high, moderate, low or critically low using the criteria defined in the AMSTAR2 guidelines (Shea et al., 2017). The AMSTAR2 authors define 7 of the 16 items as being critical and these items therefore have a larger impact on the overall rating. The critical domains are: item 1 regarding protocol registration, item 4 regarding search strategy, item 7 regarding exclusion of studies, item 9 regarding risk of bias in included studies, item 11 regarding the method of meta-analysis, item 13 regarding the consideration of risk of bias when interpreting the results and item 15 regarding the assessment of publication bias (Shea et al., 2017). The information used to answer each AMSTAR2 question will also be extracted as variables.

Furthermore, the following variables not covered by AMSTAR2 will be extracted. These variables associated with methodological quality has previously been shown or hypothesized to affect study conclusions:
•	sources of funding (not reported, none, yes – industry support, Yes – non-profit support) (Ebrahim et al., 2016; Jørgensen et al., 2008) 
•	journal type (open access, subscription based, Cochrane) (Jørgensen et al., 2006) 
•	is one of the authors a content area expert, defined as either orthopedic specialist or author of an included study (yes, no) (Assendelft et al., 1995; Gøtzsche and Ioannidis, 2012)
•	inclusion criteria (Bolland and Grey, 2014; Ford et al., 2010; Goodyear-Smith et al., 2012; Linde and Willich, 2003)  

Lastly, we will conduct an explorative analysis of each included study to identify any methodological variables not described above that could explain the discordant conclusions. If any such variables are identified we will, if possible, extract these as quantitative variables.

Outcomes and prioritization
The primary aim is to analyze the association between AMSTAR2 rating and study conclusions. 
The secondary aim is to investigate the association between the critical AMSTAR2 items described above and study conclusions.
The tertiary aim is to identify methodological variables, not included in AMSTAR2, and analyze the effect on study conclusions.

Data synthesis
We do not expect the data for our outcomes or subgroup analyses to be normally distributed. Therefore, the Mann-Whitney test will be used for independent variables with two levels while the Kruskal-Wallis analysis of variance will be used for the independent variables with more than two levels. Furthermore, we will calculate Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient between the overall AMSTAR2 rating and study conclusions. We will conduct sensitivity analyses based on the number of included patients for each included study and the years covered by the included studies search strategy. 
Significance will be defined as p-values < 0.05. If we find a significant difference in conclusions for the AMSTAR2 ratings, we will perform pairwise comparisons for each combination of AMSTAR2 ratings. If the pairwise comparisons are performed, the significance level for these analyses will be corrected using the Holm-Bonferroni method. 
Some of the extracted variables does not allow for statistical testing. We will therefore provide a descriptive analysis of these variables using summary statistics. Means and standard deviations will be calculated for normally distributed variables while medians and interquartile ranges will be calculated for non-normally distributed variables. 
All analyses will be performed using the statistical computing software R (2019).

Analysis of subgroups or subsets
We plan to investigate the association between study conclusions and the following variables: 
•	Journal type
•	Sources of funding
•	One of the authors is a content area expert
Furthermore, if the data permits, we will perform relevant subgroup analyses on variables identified as potential methodological issues not covered by the AMSTAR2 tool. If multiple new variables are identified and subgroup analyses performed, the significance level will be corrected using the Holm-Bonferroni method. 

Conflicts of interest
None

Acknowledgements
The authors would like to thank Inge Petersen, Biostatistician at the University of Southern Denmark Open Patient data Explorative Network, for assisting in the development of the data analysis plan. 
 
References

Assendelft, W.J.J., Koes, B.W., Knipschild, P.G., Bouter, L.M., 1995. The Relationship Between Methodological Quality and Conclusions in Reviews of Spinal Manipulation. JAMA 274, 1942–1948. https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.1995.03530240052041
Beks, R.B., Ochen, Y., Frima, H., Smeeing, D.P.J., van der Meijden, O., Timmers, T.K., van der Velde, D., van Heijl, M., Leenen, L.P.H., Groenwold, R.H.H., Houwert, R.M., 2018. Operative versus nonoperative treatment of proximal humeral fractures: a systematic review, meta-analysis, and comparison of observational studies and randomized controlled trials. Journal of Shoulder and Elbow Surgery 27, 1526–1534. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jse.2018.03.009
Bolland, M.J., Grey, A., 2014. A Case Study of Discordant Overlapping Meta-Analyses: Vitamin D Supplements and Fracture. PLoS ONE 9, e115934. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0115934
Boons, H.W., Goosen, J.H., Van Grinsven, S., Van Susante, J.L., Van Loon, C.J., 2012. Hemiarthroplasty for humeral four-part fractures for patients 65 years and older a randomized controlled trial. Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research 470, 3483–3491. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11999-012-2531-0
Calvo, E., Morcillo, D., Foruria, A.M., Redondo-Santamaría, E., Osorio-Picorne, F., Caeiro, J.R., 2011. Journal of Shoulder and Elbow Surgery 20, 795–801. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jse.2010.09.008
Chen, L., Xing, F., Xiang, Z., 2016. Effectiveness and safety of interventions for treating adults with displaced proximal humeral fracture: A network meta-analysis and systematic review. PLoS ONE 11, 1–18. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0166801
Court-Brown, C.M., Clement, N.D., Duckworth, A.D., Biant, L.C., McQueen, M.M., 2017. The changing epidemiology of fall-related fractures in adults. Injury 48, 819–824. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.injury.2017.02.021
Covidence systematic review software, Veritas Health Innovation, Melbourne, Australia. Available at www.covidence.org, n.d.
Du, S., Ye, J., Chen, H., Li, X., Lin, Q., 2017. Interventions for Treating 3- or 4-part proximal humeral fractures in elderly patient: A network meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. International Journal of Surgery 48, 240–246. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijsu.2017.09.002

registration_responses.summary:
Does variation in methodological quality explain the discordant conclusions of meta-analyses comparing operative and non-operative treatments for proximal humeral fractures in the elderly?: a systematic review protocol
Nicolai Sandau BSc MD1, Peter Buxbom MD PhD1, Ian Harris MBBS MMed(Clin Epi) PhD2, Asbjørn Hróbjartsson MD PhD3, Stig Brorson MD PhD DMSc1
1Centre for Evidence-Based Orthopedics, Department of Orthopedic Surgery, Zealand University Hospital, Køge, Denmark 
2Whitlam Orthopaedic Research Centre, Ingham Institute for Applied Medical Research, South Western Sydney Clinical School, SWSLHD, University of New South Wales (UNSW Sydney), Liverpool, NSW, 2170, Australia
3Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine Odense (CEBMO), University of Southern Denmark and Odense University Hospital, Odense, Denmark

Introduction
Proximal humeral fractures (PHF) are the third most common non-vertebral osteoporotic fractures among the elderly (Calvo et al., 2011; Court-Brown et al., 2017; Launonen et al., 2015). Palvanen et al. reported an average increase of 13.7% per year between 1970 and 2002 of patients older than 60 hospitalized with PHF (Palvanen et al., 2006). In a more recent study by Launonen et al. the authors reported an incidence of 379 PHF per 100,000 person-years for women and 232 per 100,000 person-years for men over the age of 80 years (Launonen et al., 2015). Both operative and non-operative interventions have been used as methods of treatment. Non-operative treatment often constitutes a period of immobilization in a sling combined with either immediate passive mobilization or delayed passive and active exercises after a period of immobilization. Multiple surgical treatment options exist, including closed reduction and percutaneous pinning, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with either plate and screws, tension-band or intramedullary fixation. Complex fractures like head-splitting fractures, fracture dislocations, and some 4-part fractures have been treated surgically with hemi-arthroplasty (HA). However, the use of reverse shoulder arthroplasty (RSA) in the primary treatment of these fractures has been increasing. Klug et al. reported a more than eightfold increase in the use of RSA for the treatment of PHF in Germany between 2007 and 2016 while the use of HA decreased by 57.1%. Locking plate fixation was used as the primary treatment in 48.3% of cases making it most used treatment of choice(Klug et al., 2019). However, no consensus on the optimal treatment modality for the primary care of PHF exist. 

Several randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have compared the functional outcome following operative or non-operative treatments for PHF (Boons et al., 2012; Fjalestad et al., 2012, 2010; Fjalestad and Hole, 2014; Handoll et al., 2017; Launonen et al., 2019; Lopiz et al., 2019; Olerud et al., 2011a, 2011b; Rangan et al., 2015; Stableforth, 1984; Zyto et al., 1997). Based on these studies several meta-analyses have been conducted to summarize the available evidence. However, the conclusions have been conflicting. A preliminary search identified 15 overlapping meta-analyses of the difference in clinical outcome between operative and non-operative treatments for PHF. Of these, 11 reported no significant difference in functional outcome measures between operative and non-operative treatments (Beks et al., 2018; Fu et al., 2014; Handoll and Brorson, 2015; Jia et al., 2014; Li et al., 2016, 2013; Mao et al., 2015, 2014; Navarro et al., 2018; Rabi, 2015; Song et al., 2015; Xie et al., 2015). Although Mao et al. (2015) reported no significant difference in functional outcome they did, however, report that patients treated operatively reported significantly higher post-operative quality of life scores compared to patients treated non-operatively. 

Three of the 15 identified meta-analyses reported a significant improvement in functional outcome for the operative intervention when compared to non-operative treatments (Chen et al., 2016; Du et al., 2017; Sabharwal et al., 2016). In the study by Sabharwal et al., the authors conducted subgroup analyses based on fracture complexity and reported that 4-part fractures managed operatively had significantly higher quality of life scores at 24 months. However, they did not report any significant difference in functional outcome between operative and non-operative treatment (Sabharwal et al., 2016). Both Chen et al. and Du et al. conducted network meta-analyses and reported that RSA was associated with the highest probability for improving functional outcome compared to other operative interventions and non-operative treatment (Chen et al., 2016; Du et al., 2017). 

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses are often used to summarize the current evidence on treatment effects and are often used by decision-makers to guide clinical practice (Mulrow, 1994). It has previously been reported that differences in methodological quality potentially can affect the outcome of meta-analyses thereby leading to conflicting conclusions (Higgins and Green, 2011; Simunovic et al., 2009). One could, therefore, hypothesize that the discordant conclusions described above are in part caused by variation in methodological quality. 

The primary aim of this study is, therefore, to investigate if variation in methodological quality can explain the discordant conclusions of systematic reviews with meta-analyses comparing operative versus non-operative treatment for proximal humeral fractures in the elderly.

Methods
The present study protocol was developed in accordance with Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis Protocols (PRISMA-P) (Moher et al., 2015). 
Eligibility criteria
Systematic reviews reporting meta-analyses comparing operative and non-operative treatments for PHF will be included. 
Systematic reviews including studies on patients below the mean age of 60 or studies on pathological fractures will be excluded. Systematic reviews that do not perform any meta-analyses will be excluded. If we identify duplicate publications or updates of the same review, we will only include the newest version as defined by publication date. No limits on publication date or language will be set.
Information sources
PubMed, EMBASE, The Cochrane Library and Web of Science will be searched using the strategy described below. Furthermore, the references of the included studies and of relevant studies identified during the selection process will be screened for potentially eligible studies. 

Search strategy
The search strategy will be developed for PubMed and will be adapted for the other bibliographic databases. 

Study records

Data management 
The retrieved records will be imported to an EndNote X9 database. Duplicates will be identified manually using EndNote’s built-in functions. The remaining records will then be uploaded to the Covidence website for the selection process (Covidence systematic review software, Veritas Health Innovation, Melbourne, Australia. Available at www.covidence.org, n.d.).

Selection process
The abstract and full text screening of potentially eligible studies will be performed independently by the first and second author. Disagreements will be solved by consensus.

Data collection process
A data extraction form will be created using Excel and piloted by the first and second author on three studies randomly selected from the included studies. After any corrections are made following the piloting process, all studies will then be extracted independently by the first and second author. Disagreements will be solved by consensus.

Data items
The following variables on study characteristics will be extracted: 
•	publication year
•	language
•	rationale for repeating review
•	PICO
•	databases searched
•	years covered in search
•	included trials
•	number of patients 
The conclusions will be grouped and classified based on outcome as follows; 1) quality of life, 2) functional outcome and 3) harm of intervention. The conclusions will be scored on a scale from 1 to 6 as described by Als-Nielsen et al. (Als-Nielsen et al., 2003). Intervention will be defined as operative treatment and control will be defined as non-operative treatment.

The methodological quality of the included studies will be evaluated using the Assessment of Multiple Systematic Reviews 2 (AMSTAR2) tool (Shea et al., 2017). AMSTAR2 is an updated version of the original AMSTAR, which is a validated tool for assessing the methodological quality of systematic reviews(Shea et al., 2009, 2007). The tool consists of 16 items evaluating the methodological quality of different steps during the process of conducting a meta-analysis. Item 1,3,5,6 and 10-16 will be scored as either ‘yes’ or ‘no’. Item 2, 4 and 7-9 will be scored as either ‘yes’, ‘partial yes’ or ‘no’. Each study will be assigned an overall rating of either high, moderate, low or critically low using the criteria defined in the AMSTAR2 guidelines (Shea et al., 2017). The AMSTAR2 authors define 7 of the 16 items as being critical and these items therefore have a larger impact on the overall rating. The critical domains are: item 1 regarding protocol registration, item 4 regarding search strategy, item 7 regarding exclusion of studies, item 9 regarding risk of bias in included studies, item 11 regarding the method of meta-analysis, item 13 regarding the consideration of risk of bias when interpreting the results and item 15 regarding the assessment of publication bias (Shea et al., 2017). The information used to answer each AMSTAR2 question will also be extracted as variables.

Furthermore, the following variables not covered by AMSTAR2 will be extracted. These variables associated with methodological quality has previously been shown or hypothesized to affect study conclusions:
•	sources of funding (not reported, none, yes – industry support, Yes – non-profit support) (Ebrahim et al., 2016; Jørgensen et al., 2008) 
•	journal type (open access, subscription based, Cochrane) (Jørgensen et al., 2006) 
•	is one of the authors a content area expert, defined as either orthopedic specialist or author of an included study (yes, no) (Assendelft et al., 1995; Gøtzsche and Ioannidis, 2012)
•	inclusion criteria (Bolland and Grey, 2014; Ford et al., 2010; Goodyear-Smith et al., 2012; Linde and Willich, 2003)  

Lastly, we will conduct an explorative analysis of each included study to identify any methodological variables not described above that could explain the discordant conclusions. If any such variables are identified we will, if possible, extract these as quantitative variables.

Outcomes and prioritization
The primary aim is to analyze the association between AMSTAR2 rating and study conclusions. 
The secondary aim is to investigate the association between the critical AMSTAR2 items described above and study conclusions.
The tertiary aim is to identify methodological variables, not included in AMSTAR2, and analyze the effect on study conclusions.

Data synthesis
We do not expect the data for our outcomes or subgroup analyses to be normally distributed. Therefore, the Mann-Whitney test will be used for independent variables with two levels while the Kruskal-Wallis analysis of variance will be used for the independent variables with more than two levels. Furthermore, we will calculate Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient between the overall AMSTAR2 rating and study conclusions. We will conduct sensitivity analyses based on the number of included patients for each included study and the years covered by the included studies search strategy. 
Significance will be defined as p-values < 0.05. If we find a significant difference in conclusions for the AMSTAR2 ratings, we will perform pairwise comparisons for each combination of AMSTAR2 ratings. If the pairwise comparisons are performed, the significance level for these analyses will be corrected using the Holm-Bonferroni method. 
Some of the extracted variables does not allow for statistical testing. We will therefore provide a descriptive analysis of these variables using summary statistics. Means and standard deviations will be calculated for normally distributed variables while medians and interquartile ranges will be calculated for non-normally distributed variables. 
All analyses will be performed using the statistical computing software R (2019).

Analysis of subgroups or subsets
We plan to investigate the association between study conclusions and the following variables: 
•	Journal type
•	Sources of funding
•	One of the authors is a content area expert
Furthermore, if the data permits, we will perform relevant subgroup analyses on variables identified as potential methodological issues not covered by the AMSTAR2 tool. If multiple new variables are identified and subgroup analyses performed, the significance level will be corrected using the Holm-Bonferroni method. 

Conflicts of interest
None

Acknowledgements
The authors would like to thank Inge Petersen, Biostatistician at the University of Southern Denmark Open Patient data Explorative Network, for assisting in the development of the data analysis plan.

attributes.title: Responsible Product Design and Other Interventions to Mitigate Excessive Gambling: A Scoping Review
attributes.description: Researchers and others have developed a number of game-based responsible gambling tools and interventions (i.e., mechanisms that directly and specifically engage with standard gambling game processes and progress to support responsible gambling) that are intended to mitigate risks for excessive gambling. The taxonomy of such tools is unclear, as is their associated strength of evidence. Such information is necessary to identify appropriate developmental and evaluative next steps for advancing comprehensive gambling safety efforts. Consequently, we plan to conduct a scoping review of the literature associated with game-based responsible gambling tools and interventions. We will search several electronic databases and chart included studies on a number of characteristics. We will construe “gambling” broadly, to encompass the full spectrum of gambling behavior (i.e., from gambling participation to clinically diagnosable Gambling Disorder). This scoping review will identify any potential gaps in knowledge and suggest key areas of research needed to advance gambling-related product safety tools and practices.

attributes.title: The Effects of Minority Stress on Depression and Anxiety Symptoms among Men who have Sex with Men in Ireland
attributes.description: A secondary analysis using data from the European Men who have sex with men Internet Survey (EMIS) 2017.

summary.value:
Secondary data analysis pre-registration template (van den Akker et al., 2019)

Part 1: Study information
Q1: Provide the working title of your study.
•	The Effects of Minority Stress on Depression and Anxiety Symptoms among Men who have Sex with Men in Ireland

Q2: Name the authors of this preregistration.
•	Chris Noone (NUI Galway)
•	Daniel McCartney (London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine)
•	Mick Quinlan (Gay Health Network)

Q3: List each research question included in this study.
•	RQ1: What is the relationship between sexual identity and mental health outcomes?
•	RQ2: What is the relationship between experiencing distal minority stressors and mental health outcomes?
•	RQ3: What is the relationship between experiencing proximal minority stressors and mental health outcomes?
•	RQ4: What is the relationship between experiencing social support and mental health outcomes?
•	These research questions pertain to propositions within Minority Stress Theory.




Q4: For each of the research questions listed in the previous section, provide one or more specific and testable hypotheses, and make it clear whether the hypotheses are directional (e.g., A > B) or non-directional (e.g., A ≠ B). If directional, state the direction.
•	H1A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, those with a bisexual sexual identity will report significantly higher scores on the anxiety latent variable than those with a homosexual identity.
•	H1B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, those with a bisexual sexual identity will report significantly higher scores on the depression latent variable than those with a homosexual identity.
•	H2A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of distal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the anxiety latent variable.
•	H2B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of distal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the depression latent variable.
•	H3A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of proximal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the anxiety latent variable.
•	H3B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of proximal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the depression latent variable.
•	H4A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of social support will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the anxiety latent variable.
•	 H4B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of social support will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the depression latent variable.

Part 2: Data description
Q5: Name and briefly describe the dataset(s), and if applicable, the subset(s) of the data you plan to use.
•	This study will use the Irish national dataset from the European Men who have sex with men Internet Survey (EMIS) 2017. EMIS 2017 was a cross-sectional survey of gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men in 50 countries between 18 October 2017 and 31 January 2018. The study was conducted by Sigma Research at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) in association with the Robert Koch Institute (RKI) in Berlin. The EMIS 2017 study is described in detail at https://www.esticom.eu/Webs/ESTICOM/EN/emis-2017/survey-report/EMIS_2017_REPORT_ECDC.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=1

Q6: Specify whether this data is open or publicly available.
•	The data is not openly accessible. 
 
Q7: How can the data be accessed? Provide a persistent identifier or link if the data are available online, or give a description of how you obtained the dataset.
•	EMIS data for scientific articles can only be requested by members of the EMIS network. This network includes people involved in the development and dissemination of EMIS 2017 or the preparation and oversight of the national reports. The authors of the current study were involved in the oversight of the national report on EMIS 2017 for Ireland.
 Q8: Specify the date of download and/or access.
•	The raw data has not been accessed yet. Permission to use this data was granted on November 29th 2019 but it will not be transferred until a data transfer agreement has been signed by a legal representative of NUI Galway and returned to SIGMA research. When this is signed and processed by SIGMA research, Dr. Chris Noone will be given access to the raw data. Summary data for the Irish EMIS 2017 dataset was published on October 3rd 2017 and is available in the national report here: http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/local/EMIS-2017_National-Report_IE_Main.pdf

 Q9: If the data collection procedure is well documented, provide a link to that information. If the data collection procedure is not well documented, describe, to the best of your ability, how data were collected.
•	Participants in this survey were men who have sex with men who were over the age of sexual consent in their country. Convenience sampling was employed, and the survey was promoted through traditional media, social media, dating apps, and NGO websites. 2,083 men provided data for the Irish EMIS 2017 dataset.
•	Data collection for the full EMIS 2017 dataset is available in the overall report here: https://www.esticom.eu/Webs/ESTICOM/EN/emis-2017/survey-report/EMIS_2017_REPORT_ECDC.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=1. Additional detail specific to Ireland is available here: http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/local/EMIS-2017_National-Report_IE_Main.pdf



Q10: Some studies offer codebooks to describe their data. If such a codebook is publicly available, link to it here or upload the document. If not, provide other available documentation. Also provide guidance on what parts of the codebook or other documentation are most relevant.
•	The EMIS 2017 Variable Manual is available at http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/EMIS-2017-Variable-Manual.pdf
The following variables will be used in this study:
Identity
Age (Q007)
Ethnic minority (Q403)
Name of ethnic group (Q404+Q405)
Ever diagnosed with HIV (Q057)
Sexual identity (Q029)
Mental Health
PHQ4: anxiety/depression () (Q327-Q330)
Social Support
Current partnerships status (Q034)
Social support (Q382-Q389)
Proximal Stressors
Internalised homonegativity (Q390-Q396)
Outness (Q030)
Distal Stressors
Abuse intimidated recency (Q397)
Abuse insults recency (Q398)
Abuse violence recency (Q399)


Part 3: Variables
Q11: If you are going to use any manipulated variables, identify them here. Describe the variables and the levels or treatment arms of each variable (note that this is not applicable for observational studies and meta-analyses). If you are collapsing groups across variables this should be explicitly stated, including the relevant formula.
•	This is an observational study. 

Q12: If you are going to use any measured variables, identify them here. Describe both outcome measures as well as predictors and covariates and label them accordingly. If you are using a scale (a set of items that have an underlying latent construct) or an index (a set of items that directly indicate a value or quantity), state the construct the scale/index represents, which items the scale/index will consist of, how these items will be aggregated, and whether this aggregation is based on a recommendation from the study codebook or validation research. If you are using any categorical variables, state how you will code them in the statistical analyses.
•	As mentioned above, the EMIS 2017 Variable Manual is available at http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/EMIS-2017-Variable-Manual.pdf. Here the variables which will be used are described in detail along with details of any recoding.

Identity
Age (Q007): The values of this variable indicate age in years. Cases indicating 90 years or more are treated as outliers and have this variable missing (ie. are coded -1). This will be recoded to a categorical variable (1 = less than 25; 2 = 25-32; 3 = 33-39, 4 = 40+) and used as a grouping variable for exploratory multi-group SEM analyses.

Ethnic minority (Q403) & Name of ethnic group (Q404+Q405): Participants indicate in Q403 whether they are a member of an ethnic minority group or not and then write their ethnicity in response to Q404 if they indicated being part of a majority group or to Q405 if they indicated being part of a minority group. These responses will be coded according to the broad categories used in the Irish census A. White (including Irish, Irish traveller and any other White background), B. Black or Black Irish (including African or any other Black background), C. Asian or Asian Irish and D. Other (including mixed and any other ethnicities). This will be used as a grouping variable for exploratory multi-group SEM analyses.

Ever diagnosed with HIV (Q057): The values of this variable indicate either not having been diagnosed with HIV (0) or having been diagnosed with HIV (1). This will be used as a grouping variable for exploratory multi-group SEM analyses.

Sexual identity (Q029): Participants could identify as gay or homosexual (81%), bisexual (13%), and straight or heterosexual (1%). They could also indicate that they use a different term (<1%) or that they don’t use a term (5%). Since the vast majority identified as homosexual or bisexual, the analysis will focus exclusively on these participants. A new variable will be computed which will indicate whether participants identify as homosexual (0) or bisexual (1). This will be an observed exogenous variable in the model.

Mental Health
PHQ4: anxiety/depression (Q327-Q330): Participants responded to 4 questions regarding symptoms of anxiety or depression. A 4-point likert scale was used to describe their experiences of these symptoms (1=not at all, 2=some days, 3=more than half the days,4=nearly every day). Q327 and Q328 will be used as indicators for a latent endogenous variable representing anxiety symptoms. Q329 and Q330 will be used as indicators for a latent endogenous variable representing depression symptoms.

Social Support
Social support (Q382-Q389): Q382 to Q389 form two 4-item sub-scales of the Social Provisions Scale (Cutrona & Russel, 1987), reliable alliance and social integration respectively. However, recent psychometric evidence suggests that these items load better onto a general support factor than onto these specific factors (Perera, 2016). Therefore, they will be used here as indicators of a general social support latent variable.

Proximal Stressors
Internalised homonegativity (Q390-Q396) & Outness (Q030): Participants responded to 7 questions related to internalised homophobia and a question regarding outness. These questions were all phrased in a way which indicates one’s comfort with their sexual identity. The scale on Q030 will be reversed so that higher scores on all of these items indicate less proximal stress. These items will be used here as indicators of a general proximal stressors latent variable.

Distal Stressors
Abuse intimidated recency (Q397), Abuse insults recency (Q398) & Abuse violence recency (Q399): Participants indicated how recently they had been intimidated, insulted and assaulted. They responded to an 8-point likert scale (1=Within the last 24 hours, 2=Within the last 7 days, 3=Within the last 4 weeks, 4=Within the last 6 months, 5=Within the last 12 months, 6=Within the last 5 years, 7=More than 5 years ago, 8=Never). These items will be recoded to approximate interval-level data by reducing the response set to (0 = more than a year ago/never, 1 = within the last 12 months, 2 = within the last 6 months, 3 = within the last month). It is assumed that more recent experiences will have a greater effect on individuals. These three recoded items will be used here as indicators of a general distal stressors latent variable.





Q13: Which units of analysis (respondents, cases, etc.) will be included or excluded in your study? Taking these inclusion/exclusion criteria into account, indicate the (expected) sample size of the data you’ll be using for your statistical analyses (to the best of your knowledge). In the next few questions, you will be asked to refine this sample size estimation based on your judgments about missing data and outliers.
•	The unit of analysis is individual participants. 2,083 eligible participants based in Ireland took part in EMIS 2017. Only those who identify as homosexual (n = 1,689) or bisexual (n = 250) will be included in this study. 113 men who identified as heterosexual, as an unspecified other identity or who did not identify with any particular identify label will be excluded. Therefore, the sample size is 1,939.

Q14: What do you know about missing data in the data set (e.g., overall missingness rate, information about differential dropout)? How will you deal with incomplete or missing data? Based on this information, provide a new expected sample size.
•	From the summary report, it is apparent that between 0 and 8% of data is missing for the variables relevant to this study. In addition, some of the items were only presented to random sub-samples. Missing data will be handled using maximum likelihood estimation so the effective sample size will remain 1,939.

Q15: How will you define what a statistical outlier is in your data and what will you do when you encounter them? If you plan to remove outliers, provide a new expected sample size. Note that this will be the definitive expected sample size for your study and you will use this number to do any power analyses.
•	The data has already been cleaned by SIGMA research. Other secondary analyses of EMIS data have not removed outliers beyond this. We will follow this practice for univariate outliers. For multivariate outliers, we will carry out a sensitivity analysis where these are removed. We will identify multivariate outliers using the Mahalanobis Distance method and this will be achieved using the check_outliers function from the performance R package (Lüdecke, Makowski, & Waggoner, 2019). We will use the default threshold of considering the 2.5% most extreme values as outliers.

Q16: Are there sampling weights available with this data set? If so, are you using them and how?
•	There are no sampling weights for this dataset. We will not create sampling weights as there is currently no reliable information on the demographics of gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men in Ireland.

Part 4: Knowledge of data
Q17: List the publications, conference presentations (papers, posters), and working papers (in prep, unpublished, preprints) you have worked on that are based on the data set. Describe which variables you have previously analyzed and which information you used in these analyses. Limit yourself to variables that are relevant to the current study. If the dataset is longitudinal, include information about what wave of data was previously analyzed.
	Importantly, some of your team members may have used this dataset and others may not have. It is therefore important to specify the relevant work from every co-author separately. If possible, mention other researchers’ work with this dataset that is relevant to the current preregistration.
•	Descriptive summaries of this data have been presented in a national report (Casey, O’Donnell, Brady & Igoe, 2019). Four other studies using the Irish EMIS 2017 data focusing on different topics (chemsex, PrEP, sexual health of bisexual men and alcohol dependency) are currently being prepared.

Q18: What prior knowledge do you have at the time of preregistration about trends in the data set you will be working with? For example, are you aware of summary statistics or the statistical distribution of variables, or do you know about correlations between variables? Your prior knowledge could stem from working with the data first-hand, from reading previously published research, or from codebooks. Also provide any relevant knowledge of different subsets of the data (e.g., a different wave than you will be using). Finally, provide information about your prior knowledge for every author separately.
•	None of the authors have had access to the raw data yet. The only summary data which the authors have had access to is that which has been published in the national report. This report only included descriptive and univariate analyses. The codebook does not provide information about trends in the data.

Part 5: Analyses
Q19: For each hypothesis, describe the statistical model you will use to test the hypothesis. Include the type of model (e.g., ANOVA, multiple regression, SEM) and the specification of the model (this includes each variable that will be included as predictor, outcome, or covariate). Specify any interactions and post-hoc analyses and remember that any test not included here must be noted as an exploratory test in the final article.
•	The data will first be described using means, standard deviations and correlation coefficients, where appropriate. Each of the research questions will be answered using structural equation modelling. The analyses will be conducted in R Studio using the psych package to describe the data and the lavaan package for structural equation modelling. The analyses will be visualised using Ggplot2. 
•	The specific structural model which will be tested can be seen below in Figure 1. The exogenous variable representing sexual identity will be recoded from Q029 to a binary variable with homosexual identity as the reference and bisexual identity as the comparator. The distal stressors latent variable will include Q397, Q398 and Q399 as indicators. The social support latent variable will include Qs 382-389 as indicators. The proximal stressors latent variable will include Q030 and Qs 390-396 as indicators. The endogenous variables will be separate latent variables for depression and anxiety symptoms respectively indicated by the relevant items on the PHQ-4 (Qs 327-330). 
•	The code for this SEM analysis in lavaan syntax is presented here:
MinorityStress_model<-‘#measurement models
SocialSupport =~ Q382 + Q383 + Q384 + Q385 + Q386 + Q387 + Q388 + Q389
DistalStressors =~ Q397 + Q398 + Q399
ProximalStressors =~ Q030 + Q390 + Q391 + Q392 + Q393 + Q394 + Q395 + Q396
Anxiety =~ Q327 + Q328
Depression =~ Q329 + Q330
#structural model
Anxiety ~ SocialSupport + DistalStressors + ProximalStressors + SexualIdentity
Depression ~ SocialSupport + DistalStressors + ProximalStressors + SexualIdentity
SocialSupport ~ SexualIdentity
DistalStressors ~ SexualIdentity
ProximalStressors ~ SexualIdentity’
MinorityStress_SEM<-sem(MinorityStress_model,data_coded,missing = "ML")
MinorityStress_SEMFIT<-summary(MinorityStress_SEM, fit.measures=TRUE)
•	Maximum likelihood will be used as the estimation method. We will take a strictly confirmatory approach to testing this model, so no model modifications will be made. 

 
Q20: If applicable, specify a predicted effect size or a minimum effect size of interest for all the effects tested in your statistical analyses.
•	The minimum effect size of interest for this study is a canonical correlation of r = .10. 

Q21: Present the statistical power available to detect the predicted effect size(s) or the smallest effect size(s) of interest. Use the sample size after updating for missing data and outliers. 
•	Using a sample size calculator available online, we estimate that we will have at least 88% power to detect the smallest effect size of interest for this study (see Figure 2; Soper, 2019). This calculator is based on formulas developed by Westland (2010). It is available at https://danielsoper.com/statcalc/references.aspx?id=89
 

Q22: What criteria will you use to make inferences? Describe the information you will use (e.g. specify the p-values, effect sizes, confidence intervals, Bayes factors, specific model fit indices), as well as cut-off criteria, where appropriate. Will you be using one- or two-tailed tests for each of your analyses? If you are comparing multiple conditions or testing multiple hypotheses, will you account for this, and if so, how?
•	The minority stress model will be supported if the RMSEA value is below .06 and the TLI is above .90. We will conclude that parameter estimates are non-zero if their corresponding p value is less than .001. The hypotheses will be supported if the parameter estimates are in the expected direction and above the smallest effect size of interest (b = .01).

Q23: What will you do should your data violate assumptions, your model not converge, or some other analytic problem arises?
•	Based on the summary information available in the national EMIS report, we don’t expect any ceiling or floor effects. There may be multivariate outliers and these will be detected and removed for a sensitivity analysis (see Q15 and Q24).

Q24: Provide a series of decisions about evaluating the strength, reliability, or robustness of your focal hypothesis test. This may include within-study replication attempts, additional covariates, cross-validation efforts (out-of-sample replication, spilt/hold-out sample), applying weights, selectively applying constraints in an SEM context (e.g., comparing model fit statistics), overfitting adjustment techniques used (e.g., regularization approaches such as ridge regression), or some other simulation / sampling / bootstrapping method.
•	We will run a sensitivity analysis with multivariate outliers removed to see if the hypothesis tests are robust to their influence.

Q25: If you plan to explore your data set to look for unexpected differences or relationships, you can describe those tests here, or add them to the final paper under a heading that clearly differentiates this exploratory part of your study from the confirmatory part.
•	Using multi-group SEM, we will explore the extent to which the relationships in the minority stress theory model vary as a function of age, HIV status and race/ethnicity.

registration_responses.summary:
Secondary data analysis pre-registration template (van den Akker et al., 2019)

Part 1: Study information
Q1: Provide the working title of your study.
•	The Effects of Minority Stress on Depression and Anxiety Symptoms among Men who have Sex with Men in Ireland

Q2: Name the authors of this preregistration.
•	Chris Noone (NUI Galway)
•	Daniel McCartney (London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine)
•	Mick Quinlan (Gay Health Network)

Q3: List each research question included in this study.
•	RQ1: What is the relationship between sexual identity and mental health outcomes?
•	RQ2: What is the relationship between experiencing distal minority stressors and mental health outcomes?
•	RQ3: What is the relationship between experiencing proximal minority stressors and mental health outcomes?
•	RQ4: What is the relationship between experiencing social support and mental health outcomes?
•	These research questions pertain to propositions within Minority Stress Theory.




Q4: For each of the research questions listed in the previous section, provide one or more specific and testable hypotheses, and make it clear whether the hypotheses are directional (e.g., A > B) or non-directional (e.g., A ≠ B). If directional, state the direction.
•	H1A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, those with a bisexual sexual identity will report significantly higher scores on the anxiety latent variable than those with a homosexual identity.
•	H1B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, those with a bisexual sexual identity will report significantly higher scores on the depression latent variable than those with a homosexual identity.
•	H2A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of distal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the anxiety latent variable.
•	H2B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of distal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the depression latent variable.
•	H3A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of proximal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the anxiety latent variable.
•	H3B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of proximal minority stress will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the depression latent variable.
•	H4A: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of social support will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the anxiety latent variable.
•	 H4B: Among men who have sex with men in Ireland, reporting higher scores on indicators of social support will be significantly associated with reporting higher scores on the depression latent variable.

Part 2: Data description
Q5: Name and briefly describe the dataset(s), and if applicable, the subset(s) of the data you plan to use.
•	This study will use the Irish national dataset from the European Men who have sex with men Internet Survey (EMIS) 2017. EMIS 2017 was a cross-sectional survey of gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men in 50 countries between 18 October 2017 and 31 January 2018. The study was conducted by Sigma Research at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) in association with the Robert Koch Institute (RKI) in Berlin. The EMIS 2017 study is described in detail at https://www.esticom.eu/Webs/ESTICOM/EN/emis-2017/survey-report/EMIS_2017_REPORT_ECDC.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=1

Q6: Specify whether this data is open or publicly available.
•	The data is not openly accessible. 
 
Q7: How can the data be accessed? Provide a persistent identifier or link if the data are available online, or give a description of how you obtained the dataset.
•	EMIS data for scientific articles can only be requested by members of the EMIS network. This network includes people involved in the development and dissemination of EMIS 2017 or the preparation and oversight of the national reports. The authors of the current study were involved in the oversight of the national report on EMIS 2017 for Ireland.
 Q8: Specify the date of download and/or access.
•	The raw data has not been accessed yet. Permission to use this data was granted on November 29th 2019 but it will not be transferred until a data transfer agreement has been signed by a legal representative of NUI Galway and returned to SIGMA research. When this is signed and processed by SIGMA research, Dr. Chris Noone will be given access to the raw data. Summary data for the Irish EMIS 2017 dataset was published on October 3rd 2017 and is available in the national report here: http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/local/EMIS-2017_National-Report_IE_Main.pdf

 Q9: If the data collection procedure is well documented, provide a link to that information. If the data collection procedure is not well documented, describe, to the best of your ability, how data were collected.
•	Participants in this survey were men who have sex with men who were over the age of sexual consent in their country. Convenience sampling was employed, and the survey was promoted through traditional media, social media, dating apps, and NGO websites. 2,083 men provided data for the Irish EMIS 2017 dataset.
•	Data collection for the full EMIS 2017 dataset is available in the overall report here: https://www.esticom.eu/Webs/ESTICOM/EN/emis-2017/survey-report/EMIS_2017_REPORT_ECDC.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=1. Additional detail specific to Ireland is available here: http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/local/EMIS-2017_National-Report_IE_Main.pdf



Q10: Some studies offer codebooks to describe their data. If such a codebook is publicly available, link to it here or upload the document. If not, provide other available documentation. Also provide guidance on what parts of the codebook or other documentation are most relevant.
•	The EMIS 2017 Variable Manual is available at http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/EMIS-2017-Variable-Manual.pdf
The following variables will be used in this study:
Identity
Age (Q007)
Ethnic minority (Q403)
Name of ethnic group (Q404+Q405)
Ever diagnosed with HIV (Q057)
Sexual identity (Q029)
Mental Health
PHQ4: anxiety/depression () (Q327-Q330)
Social Support
Current partnerships status (Q034)
Social support (Q382-Q389)
Proximal Stressors
Internalised homonegativity (Q390-Q396)
Outness (Q030)
Distal Stressors
Abuse intimidated recency (Q397)
Abuse insults recency (Q398)
Abuse violence recency (Q399)


Part 3: Variables
Q11: If you are going to use any manipulated variables, identify them here. Describe the variables and the levels or treatment arms of each variable (note that this is not applicable for observational studies and meta-analyses). If you are collapsing groups across variables this should be explicitly stated, including the relevant formula.
•	This is an observational study. 

Q12: If you are going to use any measured variables, identify them here. Describe both outcome measures as well as predictors and covariates and label them accordingly. If you are using a scale (a set of items that have an underlying latent construct) or an index (a set of items that directly indicate a value or quantity), state the construct the scale/index represents, which items the scale/index will consist of, how these items will be aggregated, and whether this aggregation is based on a recommendation from the study codebook or validation research. If you are using any categorical variables, state how you will code them in the statistical analyses.
•	As mentioned above, the EMIS 2017 Variable Manual is available at http://sigmaresearch.org.uk/files/EMIS-2017-Variable-Manual.pdf. Here the variables which will be used are described in detail along with details of any recoding.

Identity
Age (Q007): The values of this variable indicate age in years. Cases indicating 90 years or more are treated as outliers and have this variable missing (ie. are coded -1). This will be recoded to a categorical variable (1 = less than 25; 2 = 25-32; 3 = 33-39, 4 = 40+) and used as a grouping variable for exploratory multi-group SEM analyses.

Ethnic minority (Q403) & Name of ethnic group (Q404+Q405): Participants indicate in Q403 whether they are a member of an ethnic minority group or not and then write their ethnicity in response to Q404 if they indicated being part of a majority group or to Q405 if they indicated being part of a minority group. These responses will be coded according to the broad categories used in the Irish census A. White (including Irish, Irish traveller and any other White background), B. Black or Black Irish (including African or any other Black background), C. Asian or Asian Irish and D. Other (including mixed and any other ethnicities). This will be used as a grouping variable for exploratory multi-group SEM analyses.

Ever diagnosed with HIV (Q057): The values of this variable indicate either not having been diagnosed with HIV (0) or having been diagnosed with HIV (1). This will be used as a grouping variable for exploratory multi-group SEM analyses.

Sexual identity (Q029): Participants could identify as gay or homosexual (81%), bisexual (13%), and straight or heterosexual (1%). They could also indicate that they use a different term (<1%) or that they don’t use a term (5%). Since the vast majority identified as homosexual or bisexual, the analysis will focus exclusively on these participants. A new variable will be computed which will indicate whether participants identify as homosexual (0) or bisexual (1). This will be an observed exogenous variable in the model.

Mental Health
PHQ4: anxiety/depression (Q327-Q330): Participants responded to 4 questions regarding symptoms of anxiety or depression. A 4-point likert scale was used to describe their experiences of these symptoms (1=not at all, 2=some days, 3=more than half the days,4=nearly every day). Q327 and Q328 will be used as indicators for a latent endogenous variable representing anxiety symptoms. Q329 and Q330 will be used as indicators for a latent endogenous variable representing depression symptoms.

Social Support
Social support (Q382-Q389): Q382 to Q389 form two 4-item sub-scales of the Social Provisions Scale (Cutrona & Russel, 1987), reliable alliance and social integration respectively. However, recent psychometric evidence suggests that these items load better onto a general support factor than onto these specific factors (Perera, 2016). Therefore, they will be used here as indicators of a general social support latent variable.

Proximal Stressors
Internalised homonegativity (Q390-Q396) & Outness (Q030): Participants responded to 7 questions related to internalised homophobia and a question regarding outness. These questions were all phrased in a way which indicates one’s comfort with their sexual identity. The scale on Q030 will be reversed so that higher scores on all of these items indicate less proximal stress. These items will be used here as indicators of a general proximal stressors latent variable.

Distal Stressors
Abuse intimidated recency (Q397), Abuse insults recency (Q398) & Abuse violence recency (Q399): Participants indicated how recently they had been intimidated, insulted and assaulted. They responded to an 8-point likert scale (1=Within the last 24 hours, 2=Within the last 7 days, 3=Within the last 4 weeks, 4=Within the last 6 months, 5=Within the last 12 months, 6=Within the last 5 years, 7=More than 5 years ago, 8=Never). These items will be recoded to approximate interval-level data by reducing the response set to (0 = more than a year ago/never, 1 = within the last 12 months, 2 = within the last 6 months, 3 = within the last month). It is assumed that more recent experiences will have a greater effect on individuals. These three recoded items will be used here as indicators of a general distal stressors latent variable.





Q13: Which units of analysis (respondents, cases, etc.) will be included or excluded in your study? Taking these inclusion/exclusion criteria into account, indicate the (expected) sample size of the data you’ll be using for your statistical analyses (to the best of your knowledge). In the next few questions, you will be asked to refine this sample size estimation based on your judgments about missing data and outliers.
•	The unit of analysis is individual participants. 2,083 eligible participants based in Ireland took part in EMIS 2017. Only those who identify as homosexual (n = 1,689) or bisexual (n = 250) will be included in this study. 113 men who identified as heterosexual, as an unspecified other identity or who did not identify with any particular identify label will be excluded. Therefore, the sample size is 1,939.

Q14: What do you know about missing data in the data set (e.g., overall missingness rate, information about differential dropout)? How will you deal with incomplete or missing data? Based on this information, provide a new expected sample size.
•	From the summary report, it is apparent that between 0 and 8% of data is missing for the variables relevant to this study. In addition, some of the items were only presented to random sub-samples. Missing data will be handled using maximum likelihood estimation so the effective sample size will remain 1,939.

Q15: How will you define what a statistical outlier is in your data and what will you do when you encounter them? If you plan to remove outliers, provide a new expected sample size. Note that this will be the definitive expected sample size for your study and you will use this number to do any power analyses.
•	The data has already been cleaned by SIGMA research. Other secondary analyses of EMIS data have not removed outliers beyond this. We will follow this practice for univariate outliers. For multivariate outliers, we will carry out a sensitivity analysis where these are removed. We will identify multivariate outliers using the Mahalanobis Distance method and this will be achieved using the check_outliers function from the performance R package (Lüdecke, Makowski, & Waggoner, 2019). We will use the default threshold of considering the 2.5% most extreme values as outliers.

Q16: Are there sampling weights available with this data set? If so, are you using them and how?
•	There are no sampling weights for this dataset. We will not create sampling weights as there is currently no reliable information on the demographics of gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men in Ireland.

Part 4: Knowledge of data
Q17: List the publications, conference presentations (papers, posters), and working papers (in prep, unpublished, preprints) you have worked on that are based on the data set. Describe which variables you have previously analyzed and which information you used in these analyses. Limit yourself to variables that are relevant to the current study. If the dataset is longitudinal, include information about what wave of data was previously analyzed.
	Importantly, some of your team members may have used this dataset and others may not have. It is therefore important to specify the relevant work from every co-author separately. If possible, mention other researchers’ work with this dataset that is relevant to the current preregistration.
•	Descriptive summaries of this data have been presented in a national report (Casey, O’Donnell, Brady & Igoe, 2019). Four other studies using the Irish EMIS 2017 data focusing on different topics (chemsex, PrEP, sexual health of bisexual men and alcohol dependency) are currently being prepared.

Q18: What prior knowledge do you have at the time of preregistration about trends in the data set you will be working with? For example, are you aware of summary statistics or the statistical distribution of variables, or do you know about correlations between variables? Your prior knowledge could stem from working with the data first-hand, from reading previously published research, or from codebooks. Also provide any relevant knowledge of different subsets of the data (e.g., a different wave than you will be using). Finally, provide information about your prior knowledge for every author separately.
•	None of the authors have had access to the raw data yet. The only summary data which the authors have had access to is that which has been published in the national report. This report only included descriptive and univariate analyses. The codebook does not provide information about trends in the data.

Part 5: Analyses
Q19: For each hypothesis, describe the statistical model you will use to test the hypothesis. Include the type of model (e.g., ANOVA, multiple regression, SEM) and the specification of the model (this includes each variable that will be included as predictor, outcome, or covariate). Specify any interactions and post-hoc analyses and remember that any test not included here must be noted as an exploratory test in the final article.
•	The data will first be described using means, standard deviations and correlation coefficients, where appropriate. Each of the research questions will be answered using structural equation modelling. The analyses will be conducted in R Studio using the psych package to describe the data and the lavaan package for structural equation modelling. The analyses will be visualised using Ggplot2. 
•	The specific structural model which will be tested can be seen below in Figure 1. The exogenous variable representing sexual identity will be recoded from Q029 to a binary variable with homosexual identity as the reference and bisexual identity as the comparator. The distal stressors latent variable will include Q397, Q398 and Q399 as indicators. The social support latent variable will include Qs 382-389 as indicators. The proximal stressors latent variable will include Q030 and Qs 390-396 as indicators. The endogenous variables will be separate latent variables for depression and anxiety symptoms respectively indicated by the relevant items on the PHQ-4 (Qs 327-330). 
•	The code for this SEM analysis in lavaan syntax is presented here:
MinorityStress_model<-‘#measurement models
SocialSupport =~ Q382 + Q383 + Q384 + Q385 + Q386 + Q387 + Q388 + Q389
DistalStressors =~ Q397 + Q398 + Q399
ProximalStressors =~ Q030 + Q390 + Q391 + Q392 + Q393 + Q394 + Q395 + Q396
Anxiety =~ Q327 + Q328
Depression =~ Q329 + Q330
#structural model
Anxiety ~ SocialSupport + DistalStressors + ProximalStressors + SexualIdentity
Depression ~ SocialSupport + DistalStressors + ProximalStressors + SexualIdentity
SocialSupport ~ SexualIdentity
DistalStressors ~ SexualIdentity
ProximalStressors ~ SexualIdentity’
MinorityStress_SEM<-sem(MinorityStress_model,data_coded,missing = "ML")
MinorityStress_SEMFIT<-summary(MinorityStress_SEM, fit.measures=TRUE)
•	Maximum likelihood will be used as the estimation method. We will take a strictly confirmatory approach to testing this model, so no model modifications will be made. 

 
Q20: If applicable, specify a predicted effect size or a minimum effect size of interest for all the effects tested in your statistical analyses.
•	The minimum effect size of interest for this study is a canonical correlation of r = .10. 

Q21: Present the statistical power available to detect the predicted effect size(s) or the smallest effect size(s) of interest. Use the sample size after updating for missing data and outliers. 
•	Using a sample size calculator available online, we estimate that we will have at least 88% power to detect the smallest effect size of interest for this study (see Figure 2; Soper, 2019). This calculator is based on formulas developed by Westland (2010). It is available at https://danielsoper.com/statcalc/references.aspx?id=89
 

Q22: What criteria will you use to make inferences? Describe the information you will use (e.g. specify the p-values, effect sizes, confidence intervals, Bayes factors, specific model fit indices), as well as cut-off criteria, where appropriate. Will you be using one- or two-tailed tests for each of your analyses? If you are comparing multiple conditions or testing multiple hypotheses, will you account for this, and if so, how?
•	The minority stress model will be supported if the RMSEA value is below .06 and the TLI is above .90. We will conclude that parameter estimates are non-zero if their corresponding p value is less than .001. The hypotheses will be supported if the parameter estimates are in the expected direction and above the smallest effect size of interest (b = .01).

Q23: What will you do should your data violate assumptions, your model not converge, or some other analytic problem arises?
•	Based on the summary information available in the national EMIS report, we don’t expect any ceiling or floor effects. There may be multivariate outliers and these will be detected and removed for a sensitivity analysis (see Q15 and Q24).

Q24: Provide a series of decisions about evaluating the strength, reliability, or robustness of your focal hypothesis test. This may include within-study replication attempts, additional covariates, cross-validation efforts (out-of-sample replication, spilt/hold-out sample), applying weights, selectively applying constraints in an SEM context (e.g., comparing model fit statistics), overfitting adjustment techniques used (e.g., regularization approaches such as ridge regression), or some other simulation / sampling / bootstrapping method.
•	We will run a sensitivity analysis with multivariate outliers removed to see if the hypothesis tests are robust to their influence.

Q25: If you plan to explore your data set to look for unexpected differences or relationships, you can describe those tests here, or add them to the final paper under a heading that clearly differentiates this exploratory part of your study from the confirmatory part.
•	Using multi-group SEM, we will explore the extent to which the relationships in the minority stress theory model vary as a function of age, HIV status and race/ethnicity.
